events.summary: Juan II takes stock of his kingdom, reads urgent letters from Seville, Toledo, the frontier, and the Infante Juan de Aragón. Álvaro de Luna warns him about how the Infantes seek to control the crown through council manipulation, information control, and physical custody.

exchanges.text: I stand in my palace and try to take stock of my kingdom. What is the current situation? Are there any threats to my realm? What about my neighbours?

The Kingdom of Castile - Spring 1430

You stand in the royal chambers of your palace, perhaps in Valladolid or Segovia, as the spring light filters through narrow windows. Around you, the trappings of kingship: tapestries bearing the castle and lion of your realm, the weight of the crown you have worn since infancy but only now truly command.

Your chamberlain, secretaries, and the ever-present Álvaro de Luna - your Constable and closest confidant - gather as you call for reports on the state of your kingdom.

KINGDOM STATUS

Treasury: Strained but functional
Your revenues from royal taxes, customs duties, and crown lands provide approximately 30 million maravedís annually, but noble tax exemptions and the costs of maintaining royal authority drain much of this. The Hermandad (urban militias) and various towns contribute funds, but you lack the financial power of France or Aragon.

Military Strength: Moderate and divided
Your standing forces are limited - perhaps 3,000 royal men-at-arms and crossbowmen directly loyal to the crown. However, you can call upon feudal levies from nobles and military orders (Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara), theoretically raising 15,000-20,000 troops... if the nobles comply. The frontier with Granada maintains permanent garrisons.

Noble Loyalty: CRITICAL CONCERN
This is your greatest challenge, Your Majesty. The great noble houses are restless:

The Infantes de Aragón (Princes Juan and Enrique, your cousins from Aragon) hold vast estates in Castile and command fierce loyalty from many nobles. They resent Álvaro de Luna's influence over you and seek to control the crown themselves.

The Mendoza family - relatively loyal, for now

The Manrique, Estúñiga, and Velasco families - watching carefully, ready to side with whoever offers them more power

The Master of Santiago and other military orders - powerful and semi-autonomous

Many nobles see you as young and untested, and they remember the regency conflicts of your minority. They test boundaries constantly.

Popular Support: Cautiously positive
The common people know little of court intrigues. They care about bread prices, protection from bandits, and whether their lord is just. You are their anointed king, which grants you sacred authority in their eyes, but they suffer under noble exactions and pray for strong royal justice.

Foreign Relations:

Aragon: Your cousin, King Alfonso V ("the Magnanimous"), rules to the east. Relations are tense - his brothers, the Infantes, meddle constantly in your realm, and Aragon eyes Castilian weakness hungrily. The question of Navarra also complicates matters.

Granada: The Nasrid Kingdom under Sultan Muhammad IX pays you parias (tribute) for peace, but the Reconquista simmers. Both war and peace factions exist in your court. A campaign could unite fractious nobles behind you... or expose weaknesses.

Portugal: King João I is aging but his realm is stable. Relations are correct but cool. The Portuguese remember past Castilian claims.

France: Distant but watching. The Hundred Years' War occupies them, but French diplomacy is always active.

IMMEDIATE CONCERNS

1. Álvaro de Luna's Position
Your Constable has extraordinary power - he essentially governs in your name. He is capable, loyal to you personally, and has kept the realm from chaos during your minority. But the nobles despise him as a low-born upstart (his family is minor nobility at best). They demand you dismiss him and rule "in consultation with your natural counselors" - meaning them. This is the defining political question of your reign.

2. The Infantes' Machinations
Word reaches you that the Infantes de Aragón are gathering supporters, holding meetings at their estates. They whisper that you are a puppet of Luna, that true Castilian nobles should have their proper place. Some speak of forcing a regency council upon you "for the kingdom's good."

3. Economic Pressures
Several towns petition for tax relief after poor harvests. The nobles resist any attempt to reduce their own privileges or contribute more to royal coffers.

4. The Granada Question
Your frontier commanders report skirmishes. Some hot-headed nobles want a grand campaign to seize more territory and win glory. The Archbishop of Toledo preaches crusade. But would this unite your nobles behind you, or create opportunities for betrayal?

Álvaro de Luna approaches, his dark eyes watchful. "Your Majesty, the realm requires your hand on the tiller. The wolves circle, but you are no longer a child to be directed by regents. What is your pleasure? How shall we proceed?"

Several sealed letters await your attention on a table - reports from Seville, Toledo, the frontier, and one bearing the seal of the Infante Juan de Aragón himself.

What do you do, Your Majesty?
I take a moment to read every letter sent to me. Starting with the reports from Seville. I read all of them.

You dismiss the others with a gesture, keeping only Álvaro de Luna nearby as you break the seals and unfold the parchments. The Constable stands at a respectful distance, hands clasped, watching your face as you read.

LETTER FROM SEVILLE

From Pedro Fernández de Velasco, your appointed corregidor (royal magistrate) in Seville

The letter is respectfully worded but carries an undercurrent of concern:

"Most Serene and Catholic Majesty,

I write to inform Your Grace of matters requiring royal attention in this your loyal city of Seville.

The grain harvests of the Guadalquivir valley have proven adequate, thanks be to God, and trade through our port continues profitable. The customs revenues I have dispatched to Your Majesty's treasury amount to 420,000 maravedís for this quarter.

However, I must report discord among the noble houses. The Guzmán family (Counts of Niebla) and the Ponce de León family continue their ancient feud with increasing boldness. Last month, armed retainers clashed in the streets near the Cathedral. Three men died, and the city watch proved insufficient to prevent it. Each family blames the other and appeals to Your Majesty for judgment.

More troubling still: I have evidence that Don Enrique, Infante of Aragón, has been corresponding with certain nobles of the city, and gold from Aragón has reached their coffers. They gather in the Alcázar district and speak of 'proper counsel' for Your Majesty and 'the natural order of the kingdom.' I cannot prove conspiracy, but the signs concern me.

The merchant guilds petition Your Majesty to reduce tariffs on wool exports to Flanders, claiming it would increase trade and thus your revenues. The nobles who own the sheep lands oppose this, desiring higher prices.

I await Your Majesty's wisdom in these matters. The city remains yours, but a firm hand would reassure the loyal.

Your Majesty's faithful servant,
Pedro Fernández de Velasco"

LETTER FROM TOLEDO

From the Archbishop of Toledo, Juan Martínez de Contreras

Written in an elegant clerical hand with Latin phrases interspersed:

"To Our Most Catholic and Serene Lord, Juan II, by Grace of God King of Castile and León,

Divine Providence has placed upon your shoulders the sacred duty of defending Holy Mother Church and extending Christian dominion over the lands held by the infidel. I write both as your Archbishop and as a voice for many of your realm who look to their King for leadership in righteousness.

The Kingdom of Granada festers on our southern border—a Mohammedan realm that should by rights be Christian soil. Sultan Muhammad gathers strength while we hesitate. The recent skirmishes on the frontier are signs that God calls us to action.

I propose that Your Majesty proclaim a Crusade this very year. The Holy Father in Rome would surely grant indulgences. Such a campaign would:

Win glory for the Crown and redemption for Christian souls

Unite your nobles in common purpose under royal banner

Seize tribute and territory from the Moors

Demonstrate your kingship through decisive action

However, I must also report matters of faith within your realm. The conversos (Jewish converts to Christianity) of Toledo grow wealthy and prominent, holding positions in city government and even Church offices. This causes resentment among Old Christians who question the sincerity of these conversions. I urge temperance and careful oversight.

Furthermore, certain nobles have been less than diligent in their tithes to the Church. The faith requires the support of the faithful, particularly those of high station.

I remain Your Majesty's most humble servant in Christ,
Archbishop Juan Martínez de Contreras"

FRONTIER REPORT

From the Adelantado (military governor) of the frontier, Íñigo López de Mendoza

A soldier's brief, direct report:

"Your Majesty,

The frontier holds but grows restless. The Moors of Granada test our positions monthly with raiding parties. Last week they struck near Alcalá la Real, seizing cattle and burning two villages. We pursued and killed perhaps twenty of them, recovering some livestock.

Our garrisons are adequate if we maintain defensive posture, but insufficient for offensive operations. The castles of Alcalá, Jaén, and the border fortresses require repairs and supplies that strain local resources.

The Military Orders (Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara) maintain their own frontier positions and coordinate poorly with royal forces. Their Masters act as independent princes, acknowledging your authority in words but not always deeds.

I hear rumors that certain nobles advocate for major campaign against Granada. With respect, Your Majesty, such an endeavor would require:

15,000-20,000 troops maintained for months

Siege equipment and supplies

Coordination among nobles who currently mistrust each other

Significant treasury expenditure

Done well, it could seize Málaga or even pressure Granada's capital. Done poorly, it could become a disaster that emboldens the Moors and embarrasses the Crown.

The frontier awaits your command.

Íñigo López de Mendoza, Adelantado"

LETTER FROM INFANTE JUAN DE ARAGÓN

The seal shows the arms of Aragón with personal marks. The handwriting is confident, almost presumptuous:

"To Our Dearest Cousin, King Juan of Castile,

Greetings from your kinsman and devoted cousin.

I write with fraternal concern for your person and your realm. It brings me pain to hear whispers from Castile that all is not well—that the natural counselors of your kingdom, the great lords whose families have served the Crown for generations, find themselves excluded from your presence by the... ambitions of certain low-born individuals.

Your Majesty, you are young still, and youth brings vigor but also requires the guidance of experienced men of noble blood. I fear that Álvaro de Luna, however capable he may be in small matters, lacks the breeding and wisdom to guide a kingdom. His monopoly on your favor creates resentment and instability.

I offer, as your kinsman, to visit your court and provide counsel. My brother Enrique and I have only your interests at heart. Many of your nobles—good men, loyal to the Crown—have expressed to us their desire to see proper governance restored.

Consider: would it not be wise to rule in consultation with a council of your greatest nobles? To show that you value their ancient rights and wisdom? This would strengthen your crown, not weaken it.

I await your response and pray for your health and wisdom.

Your devoted cousin,
Juan, Infante of Aragón, King of Navarra"

Álvaro de Luna clears his throat softly. You look up from the letters to find his expression dark.

"Your Majesty has read the Infante's letter, I presume?" His voice is carefully controlled. "Honeyed words wrapped around a dagger. He speaks of 'counsel' but means 'control.' He and his brother seek to make you a puppet king while they rule Castile through a noble council of their creatures."

He steps closer, his intensity breaking through his usual calculated demeanor. "Sire, you must understand—if you yield to these demands, if you dismiss me and accept their 'counsel,' you will never rule this kingdom in truth. They will manage you as they managed you during the regency, making decisions in your name while you sign what they place before you."

He pauses, seeming to choose his next words carefully. "But I am not blind to the danger. The Infantes gather support. Seville shows signs of their gold and influence. If we move carelessly, they could raise rebellion under the banner of 'rescuing the King from evil counsel.' We need a strategy, Your Majesty. But first, I must know—do you intend to rule, or to be ruled?"

What do you do?

Explain to me more about how they seek to control me. When they are my councillors, do they just think they can influence me by feeding me information they curate? Is there a physical element to this as well? How does this influence look like?

"Your Majesty asks the right question. Let me be blunt about how this works—I watched it happen throughout your minority, and the Infantes mean to recreate it now that you've come of age."

He counts off on his fingers:

Information Control

"First, they control what you know. A council of nobles would insist that all reports, letters, petitions—everything—pass through them first. They 'review' these documents, deciding what deserves Your Majesty's attention and what does not.

That letter from Seville mentioning Infante Enrique's gold? A noble council would ensure you never saw it. They would summarize: 'Seville is peaceful, minor noble disputes, nothing requiring Your Majesty's concern.'

They would control access to your person. Want to speak with the Adelantado from the frontier directly? 'No need to trouble Your Majesty—we have spoken with him and can provide counsel.' Want to hear from merchants or town representatives? 'Beneath your dignity, Sire—we'll handle such matters.'

Within months, you would only know what they want you to know. You'd be making decisions based on their curated version of reality."

Institutional Capture

He continues, his voice harder: "Second, they demand control of appointments. The council would insist that corregidores in major cities, military governors, treasury officials—all require their 'advice and consent.'

In practice? Every position of power would go to their men, their relatives, their supporters. Pedro Fernández in Seville would be replaced by someone loyal to the Guzmáns or whoever supports the Infantes. The treasury officials would be their creatures, so they'd know—and control—every maravedí that moves.

Your orders would pass through officials who owe their positions to the council, not to you. If you commanded something they dislike, it would be delayed, misunderstood, or simply ignored. 'Alas, Your Majesty, the situation proved more complex than anticipated...'"

Military Reality

"Third—and this is where it becomes dangerous—they control force. The great nobles command far more troops than the Crown directly controls. You saw the numbers: you have perhaps 3,000 men directly loyal to you. The Mendozas alone can field 2,000. The Infantes, through their supporters, could raise 10,000 or more.

If they establish a council and pack it with their supporters, they effectively command the realm's military power. Want to suppress a rebellion? You'd need to ask them for troops. Want to enforce a decision they dislike? With what army, Your Majesty?

During your minority, the Infantes actually held castles and fortresses that belonged to the Crown. They claimed to be 'safeguarding' them. Getting those back required years and, in some cases, sieges."

The Physical Element

He stops pacing and faces you directly, his voice dropping:

"And yes, Your Majesty, there can be a physical element. During the worst of the regency conflicts, there were times when the Infantes and their allies essentially held you—always under the fiction of 'protecting' you or 'proper attendance on Your Majesty's person.'

They would control your household: your guards, your servants, your chamberlains—all their men. They would decide where you reside: 'For security, Your Majesty should stay at Madrigal' or wherever suits their purposes, in a castle where they control the garrison.

They would control who enters your presence. Want to meet with me? 'Álvaro de Luna is unavailable today, perhaps later.' Want to speak with a loyal noble? 'He has been called away on urgent business.' Meanwhile, their men would have constant access to you—advising, suggesting, framing every issue their way.

It wouldn't be a dungeon, Your Majesty. You would still be called King. You'd still wear the crown and sign documents. You'd live in comfort, surrounded by ceremony and respect. But every decision would be 'guided.' Every action would require their 'counsel.' Every initiative would be subject to their approval."

The Mechanism of Consent

He leans forward, intense: "Here's the clever part—they would make you complicit in your own powerlessness. They would bring you documents to sign, decisions to approve, appointments to confirm. Each one, taken individually, would seem reasonable. Skilled advisors would explain why each choice is wise.

You'd sign. You'd approve. And each signature would deepen their control and make it harder to break free. 'But Your Majesty agreed to this council structure.' 'Your Majesty approved these appointments.' 'Your Majesty signed this charter limiting royal authority.'

They'd use your own royal authority to bind you."

Historical Example

He straightens: "During your minority, there was a period—Your Majesty was perhaps twelve—when the Infante Enrique essentially controlled your household. You resided at Tordesillas, surrounded by his men. Your mother, Queen Catherine, was kept from you. I was barred from court.

Every day, Enrique would attend you at meals, during prayers, during recreation. Always respectful, always deferential, always calling you 'Your Majesty.' But when you expressed a desire contrary to his plans, there was always a reason why it couldn't be done, why you needed to wait, why his alternative was wiser.

It took a coalition of other nobles—ironically including some who now oppose me—to 'rescue' you from that situation. They didn't do it for love of you, but because they wanted control themselves."

The Current Threat

"Now the Infantes smell opportunity again. You've come of age and begun personal rule, but they see you as young, untested, and too reliant on me—one man they cannot control. Their plan is clear:

Pressure you to dismiss me or at least dilute my authority

Establish a formal council that must be consulted on major decisions

Pack that council with their supporters

Gradually expand the council's powers until it becomes the real government

Eventually, make these arrangements permanent through charters and laws you'll be pressured to grant

The letter from the Infante Juan is step one—a 'friendly' offer to help, painting me as the problem. If you accept, they'll have won without raising a single banner in rebellion."

He pauses, then adds quietly: "Your Majesty, I am not arguing for my own position out of personal ambition. If you wish to rule directly, to build your own council of men you trust, to rely less on me—that is your right as King, and I would support it.

But that is different from surrendering power to the Infantes and their faction. One path leads to your authority. The other leads to becoming a ceremonial king who reigns but does not rule."

He falls silent, watching your face.

The question implicit in the air: How do you wish to respond to these threats? What is your strategy?

events.summary: Juan II declares his intention to rule independently, secures his immediate surroundings, and plans an advisory cabinet of trusted men including Lope de Barrientos, Íñigo López de Mendoza, and Rodrigo Manrique.

exchanges.text:
I slam my fist on the table. This abuse ends now and forever. I will determine my own actions.


This starts now with just securing this room right now. Where are we? Are there any loyal men to the crown I can rely on?

They're asking:
1. Where exactly are they physically?
2. Who is in the room right now?
3. Who can they trust immediately?

This is about immediate security and understanding their position. I should provide concrete details about their current location, the people present, and assess who is reliable. This is not yet an action that needs a dice roll - it's gathering information about their current situation.

Álvaro de Luna would be pleased by this decisiveness and would immediately help secure the situation.

Álvaro de Luna's eyes flash with approval at your fury. He straightens immediately, his soldier's instincts engaging.

"Your Majesty speaks like a king," he says with fierce satisfaction. "Now let us make you secure like one."

Your Current Location

"We are in the Royal Palace of Valladolid, Your Majesty—your primary residence these past months. Specifically, we're in your private chambers in the eastern tower. There are three ways in: the main door to the presence chamber, a servant's entrance through the antechamber, and a stairway leading down to the royal apartments below."

He moves to the main door and opens it slightly, glancing out.

"In the presence chamber beyond, there are currently six people:

Two of your chamberlains

A secretary

Three petitioners waiting for audience

Your guards at the outer doors"

Your Immediate Household - Who Can You Trust?

Álvaro closes the door and turns back to you, speaking rapidly but clearly:

DEFINITELY LOYAL:

"Myself - Your Majesty knows my position. I rise or fall with you.

Fernán Alonso de Robles - Captain of your royal guard here in Valladolid. He's a minor knight from Extremadura, owes everything to the crown, no ties to the great houses. He commands thirty men-at-arms directly guarding this palace. I appointed him myself two years ago. He's solid.

Rodrigo de Luna - My nephew, yes, but more importantly your repostero mayor (head of your household). He controls access to your private chambers and manages your personal servants. He's in the apartments below right now.

Pedro de Estúñiga - Your justicia mayor (chief justice). Surprisingly, despite his family name, he's been loyal to royal authority. He's currently at the royal courts in the city, about fifteen minutes away by horse."

PROBABLY LOYAL:

"Most of your household guards - The thirty men under Fernán Alonso. They're paid directly from the royal treasury, they eat your bread, and they've taken oaths to your person. That said, a few might have ties to greater lords—it's impossible to avoid entirely.

Your household servants - The immediate ones who serve you daily. Minor people, but they know the palace and who comes and goes."

QUESTIONABLE:

"The two chamberlains in the presence chamber - Both are from middling noble families. One, García Fernández de Manrique, has cousins who correspond with the Infantes. The other, Juan de Silva, seems devoted to ceremony and protocol above all else. Neither would likely act against you directly, but they gossip and might report to others.

The secretary - A cleric appointed by the Archbishop of Toledo. Probably reports everything to the Church, which means it gets to the Archbishop."

POTENTIAL THREATS:

"The garrison of Valladolid itself - About 200 men commanded by the Count of Benavente, who holds the castle. The Count is... cautious. He bends with the wind. Right now he pays you respect, but if the Infantes arrived with an army, I wouldn't wager my life on his loyalty.

Various nobles currently in Valladolid - At least a dozen are in the city with their retinues. Some are here for legitimate business, others are watching and waiting. Total armed men in the city not under your direct control: perhaps 400-500."

Immediate Action Available

Álvaro steps closer, lowering his voice: "Your Majesty, if you wish to secure your person right now, here's what we can do immediately:

Within the hour:

I summon Captain Fernán Alonso here, confirm his loyalty personally with you, and order him to allow NO ONE into your private chambers without your explicit command or mine

My nephew Rodrigo locks down access from below

We dismiss the questionable chamberlains from immediate service—send them on 'missions' elsewhere

We move loyal guards to all three entrances to these chambers

Today:

Send fast riders to summon Pedro de Estúñiga and other loyal officials to the palace

Quietly assess which of the palace garrison we can truly count on

Begin identifying which nobles currently in Valladolid are reliable and which are watching for the Infantes

This week:

We can relocate you to a more secure location if needed—perhaps Segovia, where the fortress is directly controlled by royal appointees, or Madrid, which is smaller and easier to secure

Build up your personal guard with new recruits we vet carefully

Begin replacing questionable officials systematically"

He pauses: "But Your Majesty, securing your person is only the first step. The Infantes won't attempt to take you by force while you're alert and protected—that would be open rebellion. Their method is subtler: pressure, influence, political isolation.

The real question is: what do you want to do with your security once you have it? Do we go on the offensive against the Infantes? Fortify and prepare for confrontation? Seek to divide their supporters? Build alliances?

Your Majesty's anger is righteous, but anger must become strategy."

He looks at you expectantly. "Shall I summon Captain Fernán Alonso immediately? And what broader strategy do you wish to pursue?"

What do you do?

No actions right now. We are safe enough and we are not being eavesdropped.


I think we need to expand our cabinet with a few advisors or young nobles who can feel out where the allegiances lie with the nobles in the city for example. I need advisors who can gather information for me and that I am able to trust. Suggestions?

Álvaro de Luna nods approvingly and settles into a chair at your gesture, his mind clearly working through possibilities.

"Your Majesty shows wisdom. Information is power, and you need eyes and ears beyond mine. Let me suggest several men who could serve this purpose—each brings different strengths."

He begins ticking off names, describing each carefully:

FOR INTELLIGENCE GATHERING IN COURT

"Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Count of Castro"

"Age thirty-two. Middling noble house, but clever as a serpent. He fought in the Granada campaigns and knows how to read men. More importantly, he's a converso—his grandfather was Jewish and converted. This means the great old families look down on him slightly, which makes him hungry to prove himself and dependent on royal favor rather than ancient bloodlines.

Strengths: Excellent at reading social dynamics, has connections among the converso community (which includes many wealthy merchants and officials who could be useful), personally brave.

Risks: Some Old Christians distrust conversos. The Archbishop mentioned them in his letter—there's always that tension. But that very vulnerability makes him reliable to you."

"Íñigo López de Mendoza" (not the Adelantado, his younger cousin)

"Age twenty-three, about your age, Your Majesty. Younger son of the Mendoza family, which means he has the family name but won't inherit their main estates. He's a poet, actually—writes rather good verse—but don't let that fool you. He's sharp, educated, and observant.

Strengths: The Mendoza connection gives him access to high noble circles, but as a younger son he needs to make his own way. He can move among the great families as one of them while actually serving you. Intelligent, cultured, could handle diplomatic missions.

Risks: His family might pressure him if they turn against you. But right now the Mendozas are relatively loyal, and younger sons often become the crown's best servants—they have something to prove."

FOR URBAN INTELLIGENCE & COMMON FOLK

"Juan de Daza"

"Age forty. A commoner—son of a merchant from Burgos who became a lawyer and then entered royal service. Currently serves as a minor treasury official here in Valladolid. He knows how to listen, how to piece together information from customs records, merchant gossip, and city taverns.

Strengths: No noble connections mean no divided loyalties. He understands commerce, money flows, and the concerns of towns and merchants. Could track where gold is moving—like that Aragonese money in Seville. Invisible to nobles who don't notice 'little people.'

Risks: Nobles would sneer at your relying on a commoner for important matters. But that's exactly why he's useful—he operates below their notice."

FOR THE CHURCH & CLERICAL NETWORKS

"Lope de Barrientos"

"A Dominican friar, about forty-five, currently teaching at the University of Salamanca. Brilliant theologian, but more importantly, he has connections throughout the clerical network—priests, monks, bishops all over Castile. The Church is its own intelligence network; they hear confessions and travel everywhere.

Strengths: Access to Church networks without being beholden to the Archbishop of Toledo. Educated, discreet, and frankly more interested in learning and royal service than ecclesiastical politics. Could counter the Archbishop's influence.

Risks: He's not political by nature—would need guidance. But his loyalty would be to learning and order, which means royal authority."

FOR MILITARY & FRONTIER MATTERS

"Rodrigo Manrique"

"Age twenty-eight. From the Manrique family, yes, but hear me out—he's a younger son who's spent the last decade on the Granada frontier. He's a soldier first, political operative second. The frontier breeds practical men who value competence over court intrigue.

Strengths: Understanding of military matters, connections along the entire frontier, respected by fighting men. The Manriques are a large clan—some support the Infantes, some don't. He could help you navigate which branches are reliable.

Risks: His family name cuts both ways. But soldiers tend to be direct—easier to read than courtiers."

Álvaro's Summary

He leans back: "Your Majesty, I would suggest starting with perhaps three or four of these men—enough for different perspectives, not so many that coordination becomes difficult.

My recommendation for an initial group:

1. Diego Gómez de Sandoval - Your primary observer of court dynamics and noble factions here in Valladolid

2. Juan de Daza - To track money, urban sentiment, and merchant networks. Information the nobles don't think about.

3. One of the younger nobles - Either the Mendoza or the Manrique, depending on whether you want emphasis on diplomatic finesse or military/frontier intelligence.

You could add Lope de Barrientos later if we need to counter the Archbishop's ecclesiastical influence."

He pauses: "These men would report directly to you—not through me, though I could help coordinate if you wish. The key is that you would know what they know, not receive it filtered through me or anyone else.

We'd need to approach each carefully. Make it clear you're offering them opportunity to serve the Crown directly, which is prestigious. Frame it as your expanding your direct governance—not as building a spy network, even though that's partly what it is."

He looks at you: "Does this align with what Your Majesty had in mind? Should I arrange discreet meetings with any of these men? And how do you want to structure their roles—formal appointments or informal understanding?"

What do you think of these suggestions? How do you want to proceed?
Sounds great. Summon them all. I have plans for everyone already. I will have a talk with everyone individually to ensure their loyalty and to give them a first assignment.

Álvaro de Luna's face lights up with fierce satisfaction. "Now this is kingship, Your Majesty." He stands immediately, already mentally organizing.

"I'll dispatch messengers within the hour. Let me outline the timing—some of these men can be here quickly, others will take days."

He counts on his fingers:

SUMMONING TIMELINE

Juan de Daza - "He's here in Valladolid at the treasury offices. I can have him at the palace within two hours if Your Majesty wishes to begin today."

Diego Gómez de Sandoval - "The Count of Castro is at his estates about thirty miles northeast. A fast rider reaches him tonight, he could be here by tomorrow evening or the morning after."

Lope de Barrientos - "Salamanca is perhaps sixty miles south. Two days' travel, possibly three depending on roads and weather. Call it three or four days until he arrives."

Íñigo López de Mendoza - "I believe he's currently at the Mendoza estates in Guadalajara. That's about a hundred miles—four or five days if he rides promptly upon receiving your summons."

Rodrigo Manrique - "This one is uncertain. He could be on the frontier near Jaén, which is a week's journey, or at the Manrique family seat in Paredes de Nava, which is only two days. I'll send riders to both locations. Expect anywhere from three days to ten, depending on where we find him."

He begins drafting instructions in his mind: "The summonses will be worded carefully—'His Majesty requests your counsel on urgent matters of the realm' or similar. Honorable, nothing that suggests suspicion or desperation, but clear that you expect prompt attendance.

For those who are further away, this also serves another purpose—we'll see how quickly they respond and what excuses, if any, they make. That itself tells us something about their eagerness to serve."

He pauses: "Your Majesty, shall I have Juan de Daza brought here this very afternoon? You could begin your first meeting today, while we wait for the others to arrive. It would also let you practice reading a man's loyalty and giving assignments—he's the least politically dangerous to start with, since he's a commoner with no powerful family behind him."

Álvaro moves toward the door, then stops: "One more thing, Your Majesty. How do you want these meetings structured?

Should I be present to observe and provide context, or would you prefer to meet each man entirely alone to demonstrate your independence and encourage their candor?

And should we bring them in through the public chambers where others will notice, or use the private stairway for discretion? The first shows you openly building a new council—bold but potentially alarming to the Infantes. The second keeps your plans hidden but might seem furtive."

He awaits your decision on these details before dispatching the messengers.

The guards there—two men in partial armor bearing halberds—snap to attention. "Your Majesty!"

THE COURTYARD

You emerge from the palace into the main courtyard of the Valladolid palace complex. It's mid-morning, and the spring sun illuminates the stone walls. The courtyard is perhaps fifty paces across, with the main palace building on one side, the guard barracks on another, stables on the third, and the main gate to the street on the fourth.

A few servants pause in their tasks, surprised to see their king walking unannounced across the courtyard. They bow hurriedly.

You stride toward the guard barracks—a two-story stone building with narrow windows. Before you reach it, a man emerges, clearly having been alerted by the commotion of your passage.

CAPTAIN FERNÁN ALONSO DE ROBLES

He's in his mid-thirties, lean and weathered, with the look of a man who's spent years on campaign. He wears a leather jerkin over a simple tunic, a sword at his hip. His face shows surprise but he drops to one knee immediately.

"Your Majesty! I was not informed you required—"

"Captain," you interrupt, "assemble your entire guard in this courtyard. Now. Every man under your command."

His eyes widen slightly, then he's on his feet. "At once, Your Majesty!" He turns and bellows into the barracks: "GUARDS! FULL MUSTER IN THE COURTYARD! MOVE!"

The response is immediate. You hear boots on stone, the clatter of equipment being grabbed. Men begin pouring from the barracks—some buckling sword belts as they run, others jamming helmets on their heads.

Fernán Alonso turns back to you: "Your Majesty, it will take perhaps three minutes for the full company to assemble. Some are on gate duty, others at the palace entrances—"

"Send runners. I want every man."

"Yes, Sire!" He dispatches two guards at a run toward the palace and main gate.

Captain Fernán organizes them with crisp commands, getting them into proper formation. You count them as they gather: twenty-eight, twenty-nine, thirty... the full complement Álvaro mentioned.

Captain Fernán Alonso steps forward and salutes sharply. "Your Majesty, the royal guard is assembled. Thirty men present and accounted for."

And not only that, you are the royal guard of the king and deserve every respect. Everyone of you will always have the right to have an audience with me whenever you feel it necessary. Álvaro de Luna watches you step forward, and though he says nothing, you can sense his attention sharpening as you begin to speak.

Let me assess the likelihood of this speech achieving your goal of securing personal loyalty from these guards:

LIKELY TO SUCCEED

Here's why this action has good odds but isn't guaranteed:

Factors Working In Your Favor:

Religious Appeal - In 1430 Castile, invoking God and divine purpose is extraordinarily powerful. These men are Catholic, many are genuinely devout, and framing service to the king as service to God taps into their deepest beliefs. This is arguably your strongest point.

Material Incentives - Promising better equipment is concrete and immediate. Soldiers understand this. The royal guard should have the best gear, and if they don't currently, this promise matters.

Unprecedented Access - Offering personal audience rights to common soldiers is radical. It elevates them above their station in a way that would make them fiercely loyal. No noble can offer them this.

Personal Royal Attention - The very fact that you, the anointed king, came out personally to address them is dramatic and unusual. Kings don't typically do this. It signals they matter to you personally.

Expanded Role - Telling them they're more than just guards—that they're diplomats, eyes and ears—makes them feel special and trusted. Men want to feel important.

Their Captain Is Loyal - Fernán Alonso's body language and response will influence the men. If he's clearly moved or approving, they'll follow his lead.

Current Circumstances - They're already on the royal payroll, they've taken oaths, and there's no immediate counter-pressure from nobles trying to bribe them away.

Factors Working Against You:

Your Youth and Inexperience - You're 18 and just beginning personal rule. You haven't proven yourself yet in battle, politics, or crisis. Words are one thing; demonstrated competence is another. Some harder men might be skeptical.

The "Not Here To Fight" Phrasing - This might land oddly. Soldiers fundamentally understand their role as fighting men. Telling them they're "not here to fight" as the primary message could confuse or even insult some. The expanded roles should be in addition to fighting, not instead of it.

Grand Promises - Medieval soldiers have heard lords make promises before. Some of the older veterans might wonder if this is just youthful idealism that will fade when reality hits. "Will he really grant us audience whenever we want? That seems impractical..."

Lack of Immediate Threat Context - You're giving an inspiring speech, but to what end? If you'd explained there are threats to the realm or to your person that require their special loyalty, it would feel more urgent and concrete. As is, some might wonder why now.

Potential Noble Ties - Among thirty men, a few probably have cousins, brothers, or fathers in service to great noble houses. Those family ties might create conflicted loyalties, especially if those nobles pressure them later.

The Egalitarian Framing - "We are all servants" is humble and appealing to common men, but in a hierarchical medieval society, some might find it almost too egalitarian. The social order is divinely ordained; are you undermining it?

OVERALL ASSESSMENT: LIKELY TO SUCCEED

This speech should work for most of these men, probably securing genuine personal loyalty from 20-25 of the 30. The religious framing is powerful, the material and status incentives are real, and your personal attention is unprecedented.

However, you're unlikely to get all thirty as completely devoted followers. A handful might remain merely professional (doing their jobs for pay but not personally devoted), and one or two might have divided loyalties due to family ties or skepticism about your youth.

The greatest risk is if you roll badly—a catastrophic failure could make you seem like a naive boy playing at kingship, which would undermine your authority with these men and word would spread.

But the odds are in your favor. This is a good action at a good time with a reasonably compelling message.

The thirty guards stand at attention, listening to their king speak directly to them for perhaps the first time in their service.

You straighten your back and stride forward to address the assembled troops. Captain Fernán Alonso steps aside, giving you the floor.

THE SPEECH

Your voice rings out across the courtyard: "My name is Juan II, King of Castile. And I come to you, asking for your help."

The guards stand at attention, eyes forward. Their faces are professionally neutral—the trained blankness of soldiers listening to a superior officer.

You continue, speaking of God's purpose, of unity, of driving out heathens and building the kingdom to the heavens. The religious language is proper, expected even. The guards listen respectfully. A few nod slightly at appropriate moments—the automatic acknowledgment of piety.

"Every single one of you is not here to fight! No, you are also diplomats, courtiers, messengers, spies..."

You see a few guards exchange the briefest of glances. It's hard to read—confusion? Skepticism? The moment passes quickly as discipline reasserts itself.

As you promise better equipment and the right to personal audience, there's a subtle shift in posture. Not enthusiasm exactly, but... attention. That part landed. Men understand equipment and access. But their expressions remain guarded, professional.

"We are all servants. Will you serve with me?"

THE RESPONSE

There's a pause. Not an uncomfortable one, but not electric either.

Captain Fernán Alonso, reading the moment, steps forward sharply. "THREE CHEERS FOR HIS MAJESTY KING JUAN!"

"HUZZAH!" the guards shout in unison. Professional, well-trained, proper.

"HUZZAH!"

"HUZZAH!"

It's dutiful rather than passionate. They're doing what guards are supposed to do when their king addresses them. The sound echoes off the courtyard walls and dies away.

Fernán salutes crisply. "Your Majesty honors us with your words and your presence. The royal guard stands ready to serve the Crown, as always."

As always. The words hang in the air. Not now more than ever or with renewed devotion. Just... as always.

The guards maintain their formation, awaiting dismissal. Their faces show respect—the respect soldiers show their anointed king. But there's no fire in their eyes, no visible transformation. They look exactly as they did five minutes ago: professional soldiers doing their duty.

One of the older veterans in the back rank has a slight frown—not of disapproval exactly, but perhaps of confusion. A younger guard near the front looks earnest enough, but uncertain what's expected of him now.

They're waiting. Waiting for orders, for dismissal, for whatever comes next in the daily routine.

THE REALITY

Behind you, Álvaro de Luna remains silent. When you glance back, his expression is carefully neutral—neither disappointed nor pleased. Just... observing.

Captain Fernán Alonso maintains his salute, professional and correct. "Does Your Majesty have further orders for the guard?"

The courtyard has that peculiar quality of a moment that should have been significant but somehow... wasn't. The servants at the windows are already drifting away, their curiosity satisfied. The king addressed his guards. The guards responded appropriately. Life continues.

You realize with a sinking feeling that while you haven't lost anything—the guards aren't less loyal than they were—you haven't gained anything either. They'll continue to do their jobs professionally. They'll guard you because that's what they're paid to do, what their oaths require, what their captain orders.

But that spark of personal devotion, that transformation from hired soldiers into committed followers willing to do anything for you specifically? It didn't ignite.

Perhaps it was the framing. Perhaps they needed more context about threats to understand why this mattered. Perhaps your youth showed through despite your best efforts. Perhaps they've simply heard too many noble speeches in their careers to be moved by words alone, no matter how well-intentioned.

Or perhaps—and this is the hardest lesson—becoming a king whom men follow with personal loyalty isn't achieved in a single speech. It's earned through time, through demonstrated competence, through shared hardship.

The guards continue to stand at attention, awaiting your command.

What do you do?

WALKING THE RANKS

Before they fully disperse, you walk slowly along the reforming column with Fernán at your side. Up close, you can see the reality of your guard's equipment more clearly.

The captain speaks in a low, professional tone: "Your Majesty wishes to improve our outfitting? I appreciate this. The men deserve better than they have."

As you pass the guards, you notice:

Mail shirts of varying quality—some well-maintained, others with rust spots or missing links

Tabards bearing your heraldry, but several are faded or poorly fitted

Weapons that are functional but not uniform—different sword styles, some blades showing wear

A few men have good helmets, but others have simple caps or nothing at all

Boots and leather gear in various states of repair

One young guard you pass has a sword that's clearly been resharpened so many times the blade is noticeably narrower than it should be.

Fernán follows your gaze. "That's young Martín. Good lad, but he inherited his father's blade and we haven't had budget to replace it."

As the last guards file away, Fernán turns to face you fully. "Your Majesty, if you truly wish to outfit us properly, let me tell you what we need versus what we have."

He counts on his fingers:

CURRENT STATE & NEEDS

"Armor"
"Currently: A mix. About half have decent mail shirts, the rest have partial mail or just leather and padding. None have plate components.

What we should have: Full mail hauberks for every man, minimum. Ideally, breastplates for the senior guards. For the royal guard to look like elite troops, we should gleam."

"Weapons"
"Currently: Every man has a sword and most have a secondary weapon—polearms, axes, crossbows. But quality varies wildly, and they're not uniform.

What we should have: Matching, high-quality swords for every man. Good steel, properly balanced. And proper polearms—halberds or bills—that match. When we form up, we should look like one unit, not a collection of individuals."

"Livery"
"Currently: Everyone has a tabard with your arms, but they're different ages, different makers, different fits.

What we should have: New tabards in rich colors—red and gold for Castile. Quality cloth that doesn't fade. Maybe even embroidered rather than painted. And matching cloaks for formal occasions. Your guard should be immediately recognizable and impressive."

"Helmets"
"Currently: Maybe twenty men have proper helmets, the rest make do.

What we should have: Matching sallets or kettle hats for everyone. Nothing fancy, but solid and uniform."

"Other Considerations"
"Better boots—marching destroys cheap leather. Quality belts and scabbards. Perhaps even matching horse tack if we're to accompany you on progress around the realm."

He pauses, then adds carefully: "Your Majesty, I must speak plainly about cost. To outfit thirty men properly as I've described... we're speaking of perhaps 150,000 to 200,000 maravedís, depending on quality and whether we commission custom work or buy from armories."

He watches your face. "That's... not an insignificant sum from the treasury. Don Álvaro would know the current state of royal finances better than I. But if Your Majesty is serious about this, I can provide detailed specifications and seek quotes from master armorsmiths in Valladolid, Toledo, or Burgos."

Behind you, Álvaro de Luna has followed at a discrete distance. He clears his throat softly, reminding you of his presence.

Captain Fernán continues: "I'll say this, Your Majesty—the speech may not have stirred them to passion, but if you follow through on the promise of equipment? That they'll remember. Soldiers respect actions more than words. Show them you meant what you said, and you'll earn something speeches cannot give."

He meets your eyes directly. "What would Your Majesty have me do? Shall I draw up specifications and cost estimates?"

What do you respond?

Yes captain, draw up an itemized bill of everything you need.


Alvaro? We need to have a look at out treasury now.

Captain Fernán Alonso salutes sharply, and this time there's genuine warmth in his expression. "Yes, Your Majesty. I'll have detailed specifications and cost estimates on your desk within two days. I'll consult with the best armorsmiths in the city."

He hesitates, then adds: "Your Majesty... thank you. The men may not have shown it properly, but this matters. You'll see."

He leads you back into the palace, through the presence chamber where the petitioners still wait (they bow deeply as you pass), and down a corridor to a smaller, windowless room that serves as a counting house. Heavy ledgers line the shelves, and a large table dominates the center.

Álvaro closes the door firmly and pulls out several leather-bound account books, opening them on the table.

THE ROYAL TREASURY - DETAILED SITUATION

"Your Majesty, let me be honest about our financial position. It's... manageable, but constrained."

He runs his finger down columns of figures:

ANNUAL REVENUE: Approximately 30 million maravedís

This comes from:

Royal domain taxes: Towns and lands directly controlled by the crown (~12 million)

Customs and trade duties: Especially from Seville, Burgos, and northern ports (~6 million)

Sales taxes (alcabalas): Levied on transactions throughout the realm (~8 million)

Ecclesiastical contributions: Certain Church revenues the Pope allows you to collect (~2 million)

Jewish and Muslim community taxes: Special levies on religious minorities (~1.5 million)

Miscellaneous: Fines, fees, confiscations (~500,000)

ANNUAL EXPENSES: Approximately 28 million maravedís

Royal household: Your court, servants, officials, palaces (~8 million)

Military: The standing royal guard, frontier garrisons, castle maintenance (~7 million)

Administrative costs: Corregidores, officials, messengers, legal system (~4 million)

Debt service: Interest on loans from Italian and Jewish bankers (~3 million)

Church donations and obligations: Expected royal piety (~2 million)

Diplomatic expenses: Embassies, gifts, bribes (~1.5 million)

Miscellaneous: Emergencies, construction, unexpected needs (~2.5 million)

"So theoretically, Your Majesty, we run a small surplus of about 2 million maravedís annually. Theoretically."

He looks up from the ledgers, his expression wry.

THE REALITY

"In practice, several problems constrain us:

First, the nobles pay almost nothing. The great houses claim vast tax exemptions based on ancient privileges. They control perhaps 60% of Castile's wealth but contribute maybe 5% of royal revenue. Every attempt to tax them properly triggers rebellion threats.

Second, collection is inefficient. We're supposed to get 30 million, but perhaps 20% never makes it to the royal coffers. Local officials skim, nobles intimidate tax collectors, towns claim poverty and negotiate reductions. Our actual liquid revenue is closer to 24 million.

Third, unexpected expenses are constant. A noble rebellion costs millions. A bad harvest requires grain purchases to prevent starvation. A diplomatic crisis needs sudden gifts of gold. The 'miscellaneous' category always exceeds estimates.

Fourth, the debt. We owe approximately 15 million maravedís to various creditors—mostly Italian banking families and wealthy Jewish financiers in Castile. That debt service of 3 million annually just keeps us even; we're not paying down the principal.

Current liquid assets—meaning gold and silver actually in the treasury right now—amount to perhaps 1.2 million maravedís. Enough for a few months of operations if revenues stopped, but not a comfortable cushion."

Option Four: Find alternative funding. Perhaps levy a special contribution from loyal nobles 'for the enhancement of royal dignity,' or negotiate with the towns for additional funds in exchange for some minor privilege."

And if the situation with the Infantes escalates—if we need to raise troops, fortify positions, or prepare for confrontation—military expenses could double or triple."

He spreads his hands: "I'm not saying don't equip your guards. Frankly, it's good governance and they need it. But Your Majesty should understand the trade-offs. Cost: Even with special war taxes, campaigns are expensive—could cost 5-10 million maravedís depending on scale and duration

Military coordination: Getting fractious nobles to actually cooperate in the field is nightmarishly difficult

Risk of failure: If the campaign goes badly, you'll look weak and incompetent. Failed crusades have destroyed kings.

What You Need Before Launching:

Papal bull declaring this a crusade and granting indulgences

Agreement from major nobles to contribute troops

6-12 months to prepare logistics, supplies, siege equipment

Intelligence on Granada's current military state

A clear, achievable objective (take Málaga? Besiege Granada city? Raid and withdraw?)"

TAX REFORM - THE MOST DANGEROUS PART

Álvaro's expression becomes very serious:

"Your Majesty, this is where you could lose everything. Tax reform means taking wealth and privileges from nobles who have the power to resist with armies.

The Theory Is Sound:

Frame it as temporary war taxation for the crusade

Make it about efficiency (fixing that 20% loss) not increasing rates

Tie it to Christian duty—opposing the tax is opposing the crusade

Use papal support to make resistance seem impious

The Reality Is Brutal:

Nobles will see through this immediately. They know 'temporary' war taxes become permanent.

Their tax privileges are ancient rights, some dating back centuries. You're attacking the fundamental social contract.

They have more soldiers than you do. If enough unite against this, you cannot enforce it militarily.

The Infantes will seize on this as proof you're a tyrant destroying traditional liberties.

The Only Way This Might Work:

Start small: Don't demand full taxation of nobles immediately. Ask for 'voluntary contributions' to the crusade from those who cannot fight personally. Make it about honor.

Target the efficiency issue first: The 20% lost to corruption—this everyone can agree is bad. Go after corrupt local officials, not noble privileges. Show you're a reformer, not a revolutionary.

Create gradations: Small nobles who can't afford exemptions? Tax them lightly. Great nobles who claim vast exemptions? Pressure them for 'donations' to the crusade. Make it voluntary in name, coerced in fact.

Use success to justify more: If the crusade starts winning, if the new system works, if the realm prospers—then you can propose making changes permanent. Not before.

Buy off key nobles: The Mendozas, for example—give them a role, a title, a captured estate in Granada. Make sure the powerful profit from the new order.

Absolutely Do Not:

Announce sweeping tax reform before the crusade has even begun

Try to abolish noble tax exemptions outright

Implement reforms without the Council's 'advice' (even if you ignore it)

Move faster than your military strength allows"

MILITARY CENTRALIZATION - NECESSARY BUT CONTENTIOUS

"Creating a unified royal army under your command is essential if you're to actually lead a crusade rather than just coordinate independent noble contingents.

The Argument That Might Work:

For a crusade to succeed, we need unified command

This is temporary, for the duration of the war

Famous crusades succeeded because of unified leadership (invoke Richard the Lionheart, Louis IX, etc.)

Each noble still commands his own men, but coordinates under your overall strategy

What You're Actually Creating:

The framework for a permanent standing army

Royal control over military mobilization

A precedent that the king commands in war, not each noble independently

How To Frame It:

Call it the Army of the Cross or Host of the Crusade—religious terminology

Emphasize this is about coordination, not taking away noble command

Give major nobles prestigious titles: Captain of the Vanguard, Marshal of the Right Wing, etc.

Promise that captured territories will be distributed according to contribution

The Infantes' Response:

They'll demand major command positions

If you give them armies to command, they could use them against you

If you don't, they'll claim you're excluding the realm's natural military leaders"

PAPAL SUPPORT - ESSENTIAL BUT NOT GUARANTEED

"Your instinct to secure Pope Martin V's blessing is exactly right. Without it, this falls apart.

What You Need From Rome:

Crusade Bull: Officially declaring war on Granada a crusade with indulgences for participants

Endorsement of your rule: Confirming you as rightful king against any who might challenge you

Support for reforms: Framing efficient royal government as serving the Church's interests

Financial support: The Church has vast wealth—could they contribute to crusade costs?

What You Can Offer:

Increased Church donations from a wealthier, better-governed realm

Vigorous persecution of heresy (if that interests him)

Expansion of Christian territory in Iberia

Support for papal policies in wider European politics

Church positions for papal nominees in Castile

The Process:

We draft a formal petition to the Pope

Send a high-ranking embassy to Rome (this should be someone impressive—perhaps a bishop allied to you)

This takes 3-6 months minimum for the round trip and negotiations

Meanwhile, we cultivate Archbishop of Toledo and other Spanish prelates to support your petition

Risk:

The Pope might say no, or attach conditions you don't like

During the 3-6 month wait, the Infantes will hear about your plans and prepare countermoves

Papal politics are complex—Martin V has his own concerns, and Castilian affairs may not be his priority"

ÁLVARO'S OVERALL ASSESSMENT

He stands and faces you directly:

"Your Majesty, this plan could make you the strongest Castilian king in a century. Or it could trigger a civil war that destroys your reign before it truly begins.

The elements are sound: Use crusade for legitimacy, create institutions that seem to grant power while retaining it, reform gradually under cover of emergency, secure external validation from Pope.

The execution is everything: Order of moves, timing, whom you trust with what role, how you handle inevitable opposition.

My Recommendation for Sequence:

Phase One (Next 2-3 Months):

Equip your guard—150,000 authorized as you commanded

Begin assembling your advisory cabinet quietly

Send secret feelers to Rome about crusade and papal support

Sound out which nobles might support a crusade

Phase Two (Months 3-6):

Announce formation of Royal Council—invite major nobles

At first Council meeting, reveal you're considering a crusade and seek their counsel

Let them debate it, feel involved

Meanwhile, formal embassy to Rome requesting crusade bull

Phase Three (Months 6-9):

Receive papal approval (hopefully)

Announce the Crusade with maximum ceremony

Request 'voluntary contributions' from nobles for the holy cause

Begin military preparations and coordination

Phase Four (Months 9-12):

Implement 'temporary' efficiency reforms to stop corruption and fund crusade

Establish unified crusade command structure

Build up supplies, intelligence on Granada

Continue solidifying your advisory network

Phase Five (Year 2):

Launch the actual military campaign

If successful, use momentum to make temporary reforms permanent

If unsuccessful... we'll need contingency plans

Critical Throughout:

Keep the Infantes off-balance—never give them time to organize opposition

Never announce reforms before you have the political strength to enforce them

Every move should seem reasonable, pious, and in the realm's interest

Build your personal power base (guards, advisors, loyal officials) continuously"

He leans forward intently:

"Your Majesty, do you want to proceed with this plan? It will define your entire reign. Once we begin, there's no going back to being a passive king managed by nobles.

And we must accept that this could fail. The Infantes might rebel. The nobles might refuse the crusade. The Pope might say no. Granada might defeat us. Any of these could end with you deposed or dead.

But if we succeed? You'll have transformed Castile into a realm where the king truly rules."

His eyes burn with intensity: "Is Your Majesty prepared for this? Because once I send those first letters announcing the Royal Council, the game begins and everyone will know you're playing for keeps."

What is your decision? Do you want to proceed with this plan, and if so, do you agree with Álvaro's phased approach or want to modify it?
