exchanges.text:
It all hinges on our papal support. Without crusade, no war and no war, no unity. We must gamble that we get Roman support and to increase our chances, I must go myself. Going to Rome will also give me the chance to meet with the pope himself and build a relationship, show him I am a sincere and devout christian, ready to set my rule into the image of God.


I want to send out the invitations for this council before I leave. Let them think and scheme, everything changes anyway as soon as I present the papal bull and the crusade. And by timing the council the moment I arrive back in Castille, news will hopefully not have spread yet about the crusade, allowing me to announce it in the council first.


I want to take the coming weeks to make sure the guard is properly equipped and trained up where necessary, to establish my own council. We should also assemble those from our kingdom to accompany us on our journey to Rome. The highest ranking officials of the church perhaps?


I also want to prepare the exact format of the council. I am thinking the following: It is a gathering of nobles on the kings invitation so I can consult the realm on important matters of state. It will be held yearly and everyone who is invited has the right of audience with me. It should become the most important political event of the year.


What do you think?

Cons:
- Leaving the kingdom for months (3-4 months minimum for the journey there and back, plus time in Rome)
- The Infantes could act while he's gone
- Dangerous journey - bandits, weather, politics
- Could look like he's abandoning the realm
- No guarantee the Pope will even grant audience quickly

The council structure sounds reasonable - yearly meetings, consultative but not binding.

Álvaro would see both the genius and the extreme danger here. This is gambling everything on one move.

Álvaro de Luna goes pale. For a moment he simply stares at you, and you see something rare in his eyes: genuine fear.

"Your Majesty intends to... travel to Rome. Personally."

He sits down heavily, then stands again, pacing. When he speaks, his voice is tight with controlled urgency:

"Sire, I must speak with absolute candor, even if it displeases you. This idea is either brilliant or catastrophic, and I genuinely cannot tell which."

He takes a breath and begins analyzing systematically:

THE ROME JOURNEY - ASSESSMENT

Why This Could Be Genius:

"Personal diplomacy is powerful. You're right that meeting Pope Martin V face-to-face, showing your youth, your sincerity, your devotion—this could accomplish what no letter ever would. The Pope is an old man; he might be moved by a young king's crusading zeal in a way that wouldn't happen through intermediaries.

It demonstrates courage. Kings who travel personally to petition the Pope are remembered. It shows you're willing to act, not just send envoys. This would impress people—both in Rome and at home.

You control the narrative. With letters, things get distorted, delayed, misunderstood. Face to face, you can negotiate directly, adjust your approach based on the Pope's reactions, make promises and concessions in real time.

The timing scheme is clever. Send council invitations now, depart for Rome, return with the crusade bull just in time for the first council meeting. Maximum dramatic impact. The nobles gather expecting one thing, you arrive with papal authority and a holy war. Masterful theater."

Why This Could Be Catastrophic:

His expression darkens:

"You will be gone for at least four months. Valladolid to Rome is roughly 1,400 miles. Even traveling fast with good weather, that's 6-8 weeks each way. Then time in Rome for audiences, negotiations, waiting on papal bureaucracy. We're looking at late summer or early autumn before you return, assuming everything goes smoothly.

Four months is an eternity in politics. Your Majesty, the moment you leave Castilian territory, the Infantes will know. And they will act. They could:

Convene the nobles you've invited to council and claim to speak for it in your absence

Spread rumors that you've abandoned the realm or been captured

Pressure officials and towns to acknowledge their 'regency' until you return

Move troops to secure strategic positions

Even attempt to have you declared unfit and establish a regency council

The journey itself is dangerous:

You'd travel through Aragon—King Alfonso's territory, and he's the Infantes' brother

Bandits, weather, disease on the roads

Italian politics are treacherous—city-states, mercenary companies, rival factions

What if something happens to you? No heir, the realm plunges into succession crisis

There's no guarantee of success:

Pope Martin V is old and ill. He might not grant you immediate audience

Papal bureaucracy moves slowly. You could wait weeks in Rome

He might say no, or attach conditions you cannot accept

While you're gone, the Infantes could send their own embassy poisoning your case

Your supporters will be horrified:

Every loyal noble will beg you not to go

It looks reckless, abandoning your kingdom when you've only just begun personal rule

I cannot protect you in Rome. Neither can your guard."

ÁLVARO'S COUNTER-PROPOSALS

He holds up his hands:

"Before Your Majesty decides, let me offer alternatives:

Option A: Send Me

I go to Rome as your personal representative with full plenipotentiary authority. I can negotiate everything you would negotiate. I know papal politics, I speak fluent Italian, and frankly, the realm can afford to lose me more than it can afford to lose you. If I fail or am delayed or worse, you're still here ruling.

Option B: Send a Powerful Embassy

A delegation: Archbishop of Toledo or another high prelate, myself or another noble, perhaps a learned theologian. Impressive enough to show seriousness, but not risking your person.

Option C: Go, But With Massive Security

If you insist on going personally, we make it a royal progress. Take 200+ armed men, your full court, make it a diplomatic tour through Aragon (forcing King Alfonso to receive you with honor or look like a villain). This turns it into a demonstration of strength, not a risky journey.

Option D: Secret Journey

Go, but quietly. Small group, travel fast, don't announce it publicly. You 'tour the realm' but actually go to Rome. The Infantes don't know you're gone until you return. Risky but keeps initiative."

THE COUNCIL STRUCTURE - THIS PART IS GOOD

He nods approvingly at your proposed format:

"Yearly meeting - Perfect. Often enough to seem meaningful, rare enough that it's a special event and doesn't bog you down in constant sessions.

King's invitation - Critical. You control who attends. Make it an honor, not a right.

Consultative on 'important matters of state' - Good phrasing. Vague enough that you define what's 'important.'

Right of audience - This is generous but smart. Nobles will value this highly.

Most important political event of the year - Yes. Make it grand, ceremonial, important. The opening should be magnificent.

Additional Suggestions:

Call it the Cortes of Castile or Royal Cortes - traditional name that sounds prestigious

Include representatives from major cities - burgesses from Burgos, Seville, Toledo, etc. This dilutes pure noble dominance and gives you allies among urban elites

Specify that it advises, does not bind - make this clear from the start

Create ceremonial roles - who speaks first, who sits where. Use protocol to reinforce your supremacy

Keep the first meeting focused - Don't try to solve everything at once. The crusade announcement should be the centerpiece.

I can begin drafting invitations immediately. They should arrive about two weeks before the actual meeting, giving nobles time to travel but not months to conspire."

THE PREPARATION PERIOD

"If we have a few weeks before departure—whether you go or send an embassy—here's what we accomplish:

Guard Equipment: Captain Fernán is already working on this. With 150,000 maravedís and focus on function, we can have them outfitted in 3-4 weeks.

Advisory Cabinet: We've already summoned:

Juan de Daza (arrives today)

Diego Gómez de Sandoval (2 days)

Lope de Barrientos (3-4 days)

Íñigo López de Mendoza (4-5 days)

Rodrigo Manrique (3-10 days depending on location)

You can begin meeting with them individually, assigning initial tasks, building those relationships.

Church Officials for Rome Journey:

If you or an embassy goes, the ideal delegation includes:

A high prelate - Archbishop of Toledo would be most prestigious, but he's mentioned in that letter as pushing the crusade already. Could work with us or could have his own agenda. Alternative: Bishop of Burgos or Bishop of Segovia, if they're more clearly loyal.

A learned theologian - To handle doctrinal and canonical arguments. Perhaps someone from Salamanca.

Experienced diplomat - Someone who knows Italian courts and papal politics.

Myself or another high noble - To show this is taken seriously at the highest level.

We'd need 4-6 weeks to assemble a proper embassy and prepare them."

THE TIMING PROBLEM

Álvaro spreads his hands:

"Here's the sequence if you go personally:

Week 1-3: Equip guard, meet with advisory cabinet, prepare for journey

Week 4: Depart for Rome, council invitations go out

Weeks 5-10: Travel to Rome (6 weeks with good conditions)

Weeks 11-14: In Rome, audiences with Pope, negotiations (optimistic timeline)

Weeks 15-20: Travel back (6 weeks)

Week 21: Arrive just before first council meeting

That's five months minimum, Your Majesty. More realistically, six. You'd be gone from spring through summer into early autumn.

The invitations say 'Council will convene in [autumn]' without being too specific, giving you flexibility. But that's a long time for the Infantes to work against you."

ÁLVARO'S FINAL COUNSEL

He looks at you with an expression that mixes respect, concern, and something like paternal worry:

"Your Majesty, you have the soul of a gambler. This plan—going to Rome, timing the council reveal, gambling everything on papal support—it's audacious beyond measure.

I will support whatever you decide. If you command me to prepare for your personal journey to Rome, I will do so and manage the realm as best I can in your absence. If you allow me to go in your stead, I will secure that crusade bull or die trying.

But I must tell you: the safe play is sending an embassy. The bold play is going yourself. And I genuinely do not know which is right.

What I do know is this: if you go and succeed—if you return with papal blessing, crusade authority, and catch the nobles by surprise at that first council—you will have won a tremendous victory before a single sword is drawn.

But if you go and the Infantes seize control in your absence, or if the Pope refuses you, or if something goes wrong on the journey... the game ends before it begins."

He meets your eyes:

"So I ask Your Majesty directly:

Do you go to Rome personally, send me, send a different embassy, or reconsider the approach entirely?

And if you go personally, how do we protect the realm in your absence? What authority do I have to act? What are my orders if the Infantes move against your interests while you're away?"

The room falls silent. This is perhaps the most important decision of your young reign.

What do you decide?

We dont have to decide right now. You keep mentioning the infantes as our main rivals, but I have yet to meet them. I feel we should do so before making a decision. Also, you mention my supporters would beg me not to go. Who are my supporters anyway? I feel like I am not the king at all if everyone is against me.


I must say that I still feel like going to Rome is the best choice, but that does not mean we dont have to make it less risky. You fear that the infantes will dethrone me as soon as they learn I am in Rome. Lets walk through how this would work. Why would they noty do so right now? What actions would we take if they were to try?


Going in secret sounds like the best option. I announce I go on a tour of the kingdom in preparation for the council meeting. We travel with our court and after a few high visibility vitits, I sneak off with a few followers to take a boat from Sevilla to Rome. There I will meet up with our official delegation sent to Rome, there on a mission to shore up relationships with the pope. They can vouch for my identity if I arrive as a travelling merchant and help with our diplomacy there. If we miss them for whatever reason we proceed on our own. You meanwhile will travel somewhere remote in Castille. Maybe the Basque region? Away from prying eyes where you will keep up the act. We can disguise someone to look like me? When I return from Rome, we convene the council.


Thoughts?

**Who are the supporters**: The user is right to feel uncertain. I should clarify that while they don't have many *proven* passionate supporters, they have:
- People dependent on royal authority (officials, corregidores, some clergy)
- Towns and cities that prefer strong crown vs. noble chaos
- Smaller nobles who fear the great houses
- Personal loyalists (Álvaro, potentially the cabinet being assembled)
But the user is correct that their support base is thin, which is WHY they need to build it.

**Why don't the Infantes move now**: This is a crucial question. The answer is:
- Open rebellion against an anointed king is a big step (legitimacy matters)
- Not all nobles support them yet
- The king is present and alert, not absent/weak
- Civil war is costly and risky
- They prefer to control through "counsel" rather than open usurpation
BUT if the king leaves for months, that changes the calculation significantly.

**The secret journey plan**: This is actually clever and creative! But it has problems:
- Very hard to keep secret in medieval court (servants, guards, everyone would know)
- If discovered, looks incredibly weak/suspicious
- A merchant traveling to Rome would still take months

- The "disguised double" idea is pure fantasy, completely impractical in medieval political reality
- Such a ruse would destroy any remaining credibility if discovered

The proposed plan reveals more risks than potential benefits. Medieval courts were intricate networks where secrets rarely remained hidden, and any attempt at deception would likely backfire catastrophically.

Álvaro de Luna's expression shifts—surprise, then respect, then deep thought. He sits back down, considering your questions carefully.

"Your Majesty asks the right questions. Let me address each properly, because these go to the heart of your position."

WHO ARE YOUR ACTUAL SUPPORTERS?

He spreads his hands, his voice becoming frank:

"Your Majesty feels isolated, and with good reason. The truth is your support base is thin but real. Let me be honest about who actually supports you versus who merely obeys:

DEFINITELY LOYAL:

Myself - Obviously. My fate is bound to yours. If you fall, I fall.

Royal officials appointed by the Crown - Men like Pedro Fernández de Velasco in Seville, various corregidores in major cities, treasury officials. They owe their positions to royal authority, not noble patronage. Perhaps 30-40 such men throughout Castile in important posts.

Captain Fernán Alonso and the core royal guard - Not all thirty, perhaps, but certainly Fernán and maybe 15-20 others who are true royal servants.

The advisors we're assembling - Juan de Daza, Diego Gómez de Sandoval, and others. We're choosing them specifically because they need you more than they need the great nobles.

Certain smaller nobles - Knights and minor lords who fear the great houses and see a strong crown as protection. Not organized, not numerous, but they exist scattered throughout the realm.

PROBABLY SUPPORTIVE:

Major cities and towns - Burgos, Seville, Toledo, Valladolid. Not the nobles in those cities, but the merchant guilds, artisan corporations, and urban governments. They generally prefer royal authority to noble chaos because it's better for trade and order. But they won't fight for you unless their immediate interests are threatened.

Much of the Church hierarchy - Not all, and the Archbishop of Toledo has his own agenda, but many bishops and abbots prefer a strong, pious king to fractious nobles. The Church benefits from order.

The Mendoza family - Cautiously, conditionally loyal. They're powerful enough not to need the Infantes, and currently see value in supporting the crown. But if the wind shifts, they might too.

NEUTRAL/WATCHING:

Most middling nobles - The Manriques, Estúñigas, Velascos, and dozens of other families. They're not actively plotting against you, but they're waiting to see who comes out on top. They'll join the winning side.

The Military Orders (Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara) - Theoretically loyal to the crown, practically semi-independent. They'll cooperate if it serves their interests.

ACTIVELY OPPOSED:

The Infantes de Aragón and their faction - Perhaps 8-10 major noble houses firmly in their camp, representing maybe a quarter of Castile's military power.

Various discontented nobles - Those who lost power or privileges during your minority, those who simply hate me, those ambitious for more.

THE REALITY:

Your Majesty is right to feel you lack a solid base. Most of the realm is neutral rather than loyal. They acknowledge you as legitimate king, but that doesn't mean they'd fight for you against a strong challenger.

This is why your plan to build institutional power, create a loyal advisory council, professionalize the guard, and launch a crusade makes sense. You're building support from scratch because you inherited a throne without a faction."

WHY DON'T THE INFANTES MOVE NOW?

Álvaro leans forward intently:

"Excellent question, Your Majesty. Understanding this is crucial. Here's why they haven't already deposed you:

Legitimacy Matters Enormously:

You are the anointed King of Castile. Crowned as an infant, blessed by the Church, recognized by all of Christendom. This isn't a minor thing in 1430—it's fundamental to the entire social order.

To openly rebel against an anointed king is to rebel against God's chosen ruler. It invites:

Excommunication from the Church

Condemnation from other Christian monarchs

Loss of support even from nobles who dislike you

Civil war that could destroy the realm

The Infantes don't want to overthrow you—that's too radical, too destabilizing. They want to control you. Keep you as king in name while they govern in fact. This is why they push for a 'council of natural advisors' rather than simply seizing the throne.

They're Not United (Yet):

The Infantes have supporters, but not overwhelming force. If they moved openly now, you could rally:

The Mendozas and other powerful families who don't want them in charge

The cities and towns

Royal officials and garrisons

Church support

Even foreign support (Portugal, France don't want Aragon dominating Castile)

The resulting civil war would be genuinely uncertain. They'd rather win without fighting.

You're Present and Alert:

Right now, you're here, in your palace, with guards, issuing orders, clearly in charge. Hard to claim you need 'rescue' or 'guidance' when you're visibly ruling.

They Still Have a Legal Path:

The Infantes can pressure you politically. Send letters, gather supporters, intimidate through shows of force, demand a council. If you concede to their demands, they win without rebellion. Why risk war when political pressure might work?

Timing Isn't Right:

They need to build more support first, coordinate their allies, maybe wait for a crisis they can exploit. Rebellions succeed when they can claim to be 'saving the realm' from some urgent threat.

WHAT CHANGES IF YOU LEAVE:

Now, here's the critical part—if you're gone for four to six months:

The Legitimacy Argument Shifts:

They can say: 'The King has abandoned the realm in its hour of need. The kingdom requires governance. We must form a regency council to manage affairs until His Majesty returns.'

They're not overthrowing you—they're 'temporarily managing' in your absence. Much easier to justify.

Your Supporters Can't Rally to You:

If you're in Valladolid and they make a move, loyal officials can come to you, the guard protects you, messages go out in your name. If you're in Italy? Your supporters are leaderless, confused, don't know what you want them to do.

They Control the Narrative:

While you're gone, they control what people hear. 'The King is lost.' 'The King has been captured.' 'The King has fallen ill in Rome and may not return.' 'Affairs cannot wait—we must act.'

Force Becomes More Viable:

They could seize key castles and fortresses without fighting you personally. By the time you return, they control the strategic positions and you have to retake your own kingdom.

What Would We Do If They Moved Now?

If the Infantes attempted to seize control today, here's what would happen:

Immediate military response: I'd summon loyal garrisons, hire mercenaries if needed, call on cities to close their gates to the rebels.

Political countermeasures: Messages to all corregidores and officials, reminding them their authority comes from you. Appeals to the Mendozas and neutral nobles.

Church appeals: Seek condemnation from bishops, threaten excommunication for rebels.

You personally lead: Your presence matters. Even without a huge army, you as the legitimate king leading loyal forces changes everything.

Fortify your person: Move you to a secure location—Segovia's alcázar, Madrid, somewhere defensible.

Foreign appeals: Contact Portugal, even France, suggesting intervention if Aragon's princes usurp Castile.

It would be messy, possibly bloody, but winnable because you're here and legitimate.

If you're in Rome? I do all the same things, but without you. I claim to act in your name, but they claim you've abandoned the realm. Much, much harder."

YOUR SECRET JOURNEY PROPOSAL

Álvaro's face shows he's genuinely considering this. He paces, thinking aloud:

"A tour of the kingdom as cover for a secret journey to Rome... Your Majesty, this shows real strategic creativity. Let me analyze it:

What Could Work:

Initial cover is plausible: A new king touring his realm before a major council makes perfect sense

High-visibility visits: Burgos, Valladolid, Segovia—you're seen publicly, seeming to be in Castile

Sneaking off from Seville: That city is far south, busy port, easier to disappear from than landlocked Valladolid

Sea voyage is faster: Seville to Rome by ship, then up the coast and overland, cuts travel time versus going entirely by land through Aragon

Meeting the official delegation: Having them vouch for you provides cover and diplomatic support

Me creating the illusion: I could indeed move to the periphery, issue orders in your name, maintain the fiction

The Fatal Problems:

You Cannot Keep This Secret.

Your Majesty, medieval courts are villages. Everyone knows everything. To travel from Valladolid to Seville requires:

Your personal servants, who dress you, attend you constantly

Guards who accompany you everywhere

Grooms for your horses

Cooks for your meals

Clerks and secretaries

Possibly dozens of people who see you daily

Then to 'disappear' from Seville and get on a ship requires:

Bribing or trusting ship captains

Avoiding port officials

Explaining to your entourage why you're suddenly not there

Every single person who knows is a potential leak. One servant mentions it to a lover, one guard tells his brother, one clerk writes a letter... and suddenly the Infantes know.

The 'Double' Problem:

Your Majesty suggests disguising someone to look like you. This is... extremely difficult. You're the king. People know your face, your voice, your mannerisms, your height, your way of moving.

A distant glimpse might fool people, but:

Your household staff would know immediately

Anyone who speaks with 'you' would realize something's wrong

Medieval people are suspicious and observant—their lives depend on reading people

If discovered, it's humiliating and destroys all credibility

Time Still Required:

Even by sea, Seville to Rome is still 6-8 weeks round trip minimum, plus time in Rome. You're talking about 3-4 months, possibly more. Very hard to maintain a deception that long.

If the Ruse Is Discovered:

This is perhaps the worst outcome. If people learn you:

Deceived your own court and officials

Snuck out of your kingdom in disguise

Left a fraud in your place

You look weak, untrustworthy, and afraid. The Infantes would have a field day: 'Our king abandoned us in secret, leaving a puppet! This proves he cannot rule!'

It would be worse than openly leaving, because it suggests you knew you couldn't leave openly—that you're not strong enough to do so.

A Modified Version That Might Work Better:

Semi-Public Departure:

Announce you're going on pilgrimage to various shrines (Santiago de Compostela is in northwest Spain, very prestigious pilgrimage site)

Make this religious and public—pious kings go on pilgrimage

Leaves a core behind - Ten to fifteen guards remain in Valladolid under Captain Fernán, providing security for the palace and Álvaro.

More flexible - Smaller group travels faster, costs less, can adapt more easily.

Balanced risk - If disaster strikes, you haven't lost all your loyal troops.

Disadvantages:

Divided loyalty concerns - The guards left behind might face pressure from the Infantes. Though if Fernán stays with you and takes the most reliable men, this helps.

Less impressive - Fifteen men is respectable but not overwhelming. In Rome, might look less regal.

The left-behind guards are vulnerable - If the Infantes move against the palace, 10-15 men can't hold it against a determined assault.

IF YOU TAKE A SMALL ESCORT (5-10 Men):

Advantages:

Fast, flexible travel - Small group moves quickly, attracts less attention

Most guards stay to secure Valladolid - Strong defensive presence remains

Lower cost - Significantly cheaper to maintain

Could be more appropriate for 'humble pilgrimage' - Less military, more devotional appearance

Disadvantages:

Potentially inadequate security - Ten men might not be enough if you face real threats

Looks less kingly - In Rome, appearing with only a handful of guards might seem weak

Limited deterrent - Not enough to make hostile nobles think twice

ÁLVARO'S RECOMMENDATION

He stands and paces:

"Your Majesty, I recommend taking twenty to twenty-five men—about two-thirds to three-quarters of your guard.

Here's why:

Security: Twenty men is enough for serious protection. You can post sentries, rotate watches, respond to threats. It's a real military force, not just symbolic.

Royal Dignity: In Rome, arriving with twenty armed men in your new livery, disciplined and impressive, makes a statement. The Pope sees a king, not a supplicant.

Leaves a Core Behind: Captain Fernán Alonso should travel with you—he's personally loyal and the men follow him. But leave his senior sergeant (I'll identify the second most reliable man) in command of eight to ten guards in Valladolid. This gives Álvaro and the palace some protection.

Practicality: Twenty men is manageable logistically. Not so large that travel becomes a nightmare, but substantial enough for all the benefits.

Selection: You take the most reliable men. Anyone we're uncertain about stays behind where we can watch them.

WHO ELSE TRAVELS WITH YOU:

Beyond the guard, Your Majesty will need:

Essential:

Your confessor - Critical for the pilgrimage and Rome meetings. He provides spiritual guidance and can witness your sincerity.

A senior cleric - Perhaps the Bishop of Burgos if we can arrange it, or at minimum a respected abbot. Someone who can speak authoritatively in Rome.

A secretary/clerk - To handle correspondence, documents, the formal papal bull when you receive it.

Personal servants - Chamberlain, body servant, at least 2-3 people who attend you personally.

Physician - Four to six months traveling, you need medical care if you fall ill.

Highly Desirable:

One of your new advisors - Perhaps Diego Gómez de Sandoval or Juan de Daza once you've met them. Someone intelligent who can observe, advise, and witness your success.

A diplomat familiar with Rome - If we can find one quickly, someone who knows how papal audiences work, who to bribe, which cardinals matter.

Support Staff:

Grooms for horses

Cook and kitchen servants

Guards' attendants

Perhaps 10-15 additional support personnel

Total expedition size: 40-50 people

This is substantial but manageable. A king traveling with forty to fifty people is appropriate and expected."

THE COMMAND QUESTION

Álvaro's expression becomes more serious:

"Your Majesty, there's another consideration: Do I accompany you, or stay to manage the realm?

If I Come With You:

Advantages:

You have your most trusted, most experienced advisor personally present

I can handle negotiations in Rome—I know how these work

We can make decisions together in real time

The guard and your staff all know and respect me—leadership is clear

Disadvantages:

The realm has no strong hand managing it in your absence

The Infantes face much less resistance if they move

Royal officials have no clear authority figure to rally around

Some nobles might see it as both of us abandoning Castile

If I Stay Behind:

Advantages:

I can manage the realm, issue orders in your name, coordinate with loyal officials

The Infantes face an opponent—they can't simply act unopposed

Continuity of government is maintained

If they try anything, I can rally resistance until you return

Disadvantages:

You're without your most trusted advisor during crucial negotiations

Decisions in Rome must be made by you alone or with less experienced counsel

If something happens to you, I'm not there to help

The expedition lacks clear political leadership beyond you

My Honest Recommendation:

I should stay. Here's why:

You're going to Rome precisely because you need papal authority to counterbalance the Infantes. While you're securing that authority, someone must hold your position at home. If both of us are gone, there's a vacuum.

Moreover, Your Majesty, this journey is about you demonstrating your own capability and initiative. Arriving in Rome with your powerful Constable doing the talking makes you look like my puppet—exactly what the Infantes claim. Arriving alone (with appropriate clerical and noble support, but no one who overshadows you) and successfully negotiating with the Pope? That proves you're a king in your own right.

It's riskier for you, but it's better politics.

Alternative Compromise:

I accompany you to Santiago (2-3 weeks journey), ensuring the pilgrimage starts smoothly and you're safely through any dangerous territory. Then I return to Valladolid to manage affairs while you continue to Rome. This gives you my counsel for the Castilian portion and leaves me positioned to hold things together during the Rome portion."

He looks at you directly:

"So, Your Majesty:

How many guards? - I recommend 20-25, but it's your decision

Do I come or stay? - I recommend staying, or the compromise of accompanying you to Santiago only

Who else travels with you? - We need to identify the right confessor, cleric, and advisor

What are your commands?"

What do you decide?

events.summary: Juan II chooses Fray Hernando de Talavera as his new confessor over two other candidates, valuing his youth, humility, and pure faith. The choice also serves a strategic purpose — Juan needs a travel companion for his pilgrimage who can keep up physically.

exchanges.text: Who is my confessor actually?

Álvaro pauses, and you realize you've asked a question he should have addressed earlier. His expression shows a flicker of concern.

"Your Majesty's confessor... that's actually an important gap we need to address."

He sits down, choosing his words carefully:

"During your minority, you had several confessors assigned by the regency council—men chosen more for political reliability than spiritual depth. The most recent was Father Gonzalo, a Franciscan friar, but he passed away this past winter. God rest his soul.

Since then, Your Majesty has been... between confessors. You've made confessions to whatever priest was available when needed, but you haven't appointed a permanent royal confessor. This is, frankly, something we should have handled by now."

He stands and paces:

THE IMPORTANCE OF A CONFESSOR

"Your Majesty, a king's confessor is more than just the priest who hears your sins. He becomes:

Your spiritual advisor - guiding your conscience on moral matters

A confidant - one of the few people who sees you at your most vulnerable and must keep your secrets absolutely

Political counsel - whether we like it or not, confessors often influence policy through the lens of morality

Witness to your piety - his testimony about your devotion matters to the Church and realm

Potential ambassador - educated confessors can serve diplomatic roles

For this journey to Rome, having the right confessor is crucial. The Pope will likely speak with your confessor privately to assess your true character and intentions."

CANDIDATES FOR ROYAL CONFESSOR

Álvaro begins outlining options:

"Fray Pablo de Santa María"

"Age: About fifty-five. A Dominican friar from Burgos.

Background: He comes from a converso family—his father was a rabbi who converted to Christianity and became Bishop of Burgos. Fray Pablo himself is deeply learned, speaks Latin, Hebrew, and Arabic fluently, and is passionate about defending the faith.

Strengths:

Brilliant theologian who could hold his own with papal scholars

Understanding of both Jewish and Christian theology (useful given the religious diversity of your realm)

Intense personal piety—genuinely devout, not just political

No ties to the great noble families

Relatively young and energetic for the journey

Potential Issues:

Some Old Christians distrust conversos, even ones who became friars

Can be intellectually intense and demanding—might challenge Your Majesty's decisions on moral grounds

The Archbishop of Toledo dislikes him (professional rivalry)

My Assessment: He would be impressive in Rome, fiercely loyal to you personally, and genuinely helpful as a spiritual guide. But he's not a 'safe' choice—he has opinions and will express them."

"Father Íñigo de Mendoza"

"Age: Mid-forties. A Franciscan friar.

Background: Yes, from that Mendoza family, but he took religious vows young and has spent his life in monasteries and missions. Currently serves at a monastery near Valladolid.

Strengths:

The Mendoza connection could be useful—shows you honor their family

Well-educated and diplomatic

Known for gentle temperament and political acumen

Would be acceptable to virtually everyone

Good at navigating court politics

Potential Issues:

Might report back to his family—divided loyalties?

Perhaps too political, not spiritual enough?

Could be seen as you being influenced by the Mendozas

My Assessment: A safe, respectable choice. Would serve competently. But would he truly be your man, or his family's?"

"Fray Lope de Barrientos"

"Age: About forty-five. The Dominican friar I mentioned earlier as a potential advisor.

Background: Currently teaching at Salamanca, brilliant scholar, expert in theology and natural philosophy.

Strengths:

Exceptional intellect—could impress the papal curia

No political connections to nobles—completely independent

Deeply knowledgeable about Church law and doctrine

Passionate about learning and truth

Would be absolutely loyal to you personally

Potential Issues:

More scholar than pastor—better at theology than understanding human hearts

Relatively unknown—no established reputation

Might be too intellectual, not mystical enough for a confessor's role

My Assessment: Brilliant mind, would make an excellent advisor. As a confessor? Perhaps slightly unconventional, but could work if Your Majesty values intellectual partnership."

"Father Alonso de Cartagena"

"Age: Late forties. A secular priest and scholar, currently serving in Burgos.

Background: Another converso—son of the same former rabbi who became bishop. Brother to Fray Pablo. Exceptionally learned, has already traveled to the Council of Basel as a Church diplomat.

Strengths:

Diplomatic experience—knows how Church politics work

Has been to Rome before—understands the environment

Sophisticated, worldly, politically astute

Excellent connections in the Church hierarchy

Speaks multiple languages

Potential Issues:

Perhaps too worldly? More diplomat than confessor?

The converso background again

Might try to use the position for his own Church career

My Assessment: If you want someone who can navigate Rome expertly and handle complex negotiations, he's your man. If you want someone primarily for spiritual guidance, perhaps not."

"Fray Hernando de Talavera"

"Age: Early thirties. A young Hieronymite monk.

Background: From a humble background, rose through merit and devotion. Currently serves at a monastery in Toledo. Known for extreme personal piety, charity work, and moral rigor.

Strengths:

Genuinely holy—the kind of man people instinctively trust

Young enough to relate to Your Majesty's age

No political connections whatsoever

Would inspire confidence in Rome about your spiritual sincerity

Humble background means completely dependent on your favor

Potential Issues:

Very young and inexperienced for such a high position

Extremely strict morally—might be challenging to deal with

Limited education compared to others (though still well-trained)

Unknown to the papal curia—no existing connections

My Assessment: If you want a confessor who will keep you spiritually honest and whom the Pope will see as genuine, he's excellent. If you need sophisticated political counsel, less so."

ÁLVARO'S RECOMMENDATION

"Your Majesty, you need to choose based on what you value most:

For Rome Success & Diplomatic Skill: Father Alonso de Cartagena - He knows how to navigate the papal court and has experience there.

For Intellectual Partnership: Fray Lope de Barrientos - Brilliant mind who can debate theology and advise on complex matters.

For Genuine Spiritual Guidance: Fray Hernando de Talavera - Will keep your soul honest and inspire confidence in your piety.

For Political Balance & Respectability: Father Íñigo de Mendoza - Safe choice that offends no one.

For Passionate Advocacy & Loyalty: Fray Pablo de Santa María - Will fight for you intellectually and spiritually, completely devoted to your cause.

My personal recommendation: Either Fray Pablo de Santa María or Father Alonso de Cartagena. Both are brilliant, both can handle Rome, both are conversos which means they need you more than the nobles—ensuring loyalty.

If you want someone more focused on spiritual devotion over political skill, Fray Hernando is the choice.

But Your Majesty, this is deeply personal. You'll be confessing your sins to this man, trusting him with your conscience. Who do you feel drawn to?"

Álvaro looks at you expectantly:

"We can arrange for you to meet any or all of these men before deciding. Or if Your Majesty already knows who feels right, I can have him summoned within days to begin serving as your confessor.

Who would you like to meet, or do you want to make an appointment now?"

Who interests you as a potential confessor?

I have made my choice. Fray Hernando, he is young and since I want us to travel fast when needed, I expect him to keep up. I also like how he is a pure christian, the kind of christian I like to be.


Send for him immediately.


And by the way, we include no-one into our full plan, this stays between just you and me. I will manage my confessions to go the way they need to go.

Álvaro's expression shifts—first approval at your choice, then something more complex when you mention managing your confessions. He's silent for a moment, then nods slowly.

"Fray Hernando de Talavera. A good choice, Your Majesty. His youth and piety will serve you well, and he can indeed keep pace on a demanding journey."

He moves toward the door to summon a messenger, then pauses and turns back, his voice lower:

"Your Majesty... I understand the need for absolute secrecy. I will share nothing of our full plan with anyone, including Fray Hernando. But..."

He chooses his words carefully:

"Managing one's confessions is a dangerous game, even for kings. The whole point of confession is honesty before God. If you withhold from your confessor, you withhold from your own soul. I'm not a theologian, but I've seen men—powerful men—destroy themselves by lying even in the confessional, thinking they could manage that relationship like any other."

He holds up a hand before you can respond:

"I say this once, and then never again. I understand the political necessity. Do what you must. But remember: Fray Hernando's value to you in Rome is precisely his genuine piety. If the Pope senses your confessor is just another political tool, it undermines everything."

Then his expression clears, back to business:

"But you are king, and this is your decision. I will say nothing to Fray Hernando beyond that you've chosen him as royal confessor and require his immediate attendance."

ARRANGING HERNANDO'S ARRIVAL

Álvaro opens the door and speaks to a guard outside: "Summon my secretary. Immediately."

Within moments, a clerk appears. Álvaro dictates rapidly:

"Draft a royal summons to Fray Hernando de Talavera of the Hieronymite Order, currently at the Monastery of Toledo. The King has chosen him to serve as Royal Confessor. He is to depart for Valladolid immediately upon receipt of this message. Send our fastest rider. I want him here within five days."

The secretary bows and hurries off.

Álvaro turns back to you: "Toledo is about three days' hard ride from here. The messenger leaves within the hour, reaches the monastery tomorrow evening, Fray Hernando can depart the morning after, and arrives here in three more days. Five days total, possibly four if he rides quickly."

IMMEDIATE NEXT STEPS

"Your Majesty, we have several urgent matters to arrange. Let me summarize what needs to happen immediately:

Today:

✓ Fray Hernando summoned

Authorization for Captain Fernán's guard equipment already given (he's working on specifications)

Continue meeting with your arriving advisors (Juan de Daza should arrive this afternoon)

This Week:

Arrange the meeting with the Infantes (most critical)

Continue receiving your advisory cabinet as they arrive

Begin planning the pilgrimage logistics

Draft the Royal Council invitations (to discuss with the Infantes)

Within Two Weeks:

Assemble and dispatch the advance delegation to Rome

Finalize guard equipment orders

Meet with potential bishops/clerics for the Rome journey

THE INFANTES MEETING - URGENT

"Your Majesty, we need to arrange this meeting soon. The letter from Infante Juan is waiting for a response, and delay will make them suspicious.

Options for the meeting:

1. Here in Valladolid

Shows confidence—you're receiving them on your ground

Your guards, your palace, your control

But they might refuse, claiming it's too much like being summoned by a subordinate

2. Neutral Location

Perhaps Medina del Campo (30 miles south—important market town, neutral ground)

Shows respect for their position

Neither side has military advantage

Takes 1-2 days to arrange

3. You visit them

Shows remarkable confidence or could be seen as weakness

Risky—you're on their territory

But might flatter them and make them overconfident

My recommendation: Neutral ground at Medina del Campo. Dignified, appropriate for peers meeting to discuss the realm, neither presumptuous nor weak.

Timing: As soon as possible. I can send a message today proposing we meet in five to seven days—gives them time to travel, gives you time to prepare, and shows you're taking their letter seriously.

Who attends:

You and perhaps 2-3 attendants (show you're not afraid, not bringing an army)

I should probably attend as Constable (expected) but remain mostly silent—this is your meeting

They'll bring their own retinue

Does Your Majesty want me to send that invitation today?"

He waits, clearly eager to keep momentum going while you have the initiative.

What are your orders? Should we arrange the Infantes meeting? Any other immediate concerns?

events.summary: Juan II spends a week in preparation: training in combat with Captain Fernán (sword, mounted combat, physical conditioning), rehearsing his role for the upcoming meeting with the Infantes, and assembling his advisory cabinet.

exchanges.text: Great. Keep summoning my cabinet. I want to have them installed as soon as possible. And set up a meet with the infantes. This is our important next move.

Álvaro nods with satisfaction. "Excellent, Your Majesty. Clear priorities. Let me execute both immediately."

He strides to the door and calls for messengers and secretaries. Within minutes, the room fills with purposeful activity as clerks arrive with writing materials.

ADVISORY CABINET - STATUS UPDATE

"The summons I sent earlier are already en route, Your Majesty. Current status:

Juan de Daza - Should arrive from the treasury offices here in Valladolid within the hour. You can meet with him this very afternoon.

Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Count of Castro - Messenger reached his estates this morning. He should arrive tomorrow evening or the morning after. Two days maximum.

Lope de Barrientos - Rider departed for Salamanca at dawn. He'll arrive in three to four days.

Íñigo López de Mendoza - Message sent to Guadalajara. Four to five days.

Rodrigo Manrique - Riders sent to both his possible locations. Three to ten days depending on where we find him.

Within a week, you'll have at least three of them here. All five within ten days."

THE INFANTES MEETING - ARRANGEMENTS

Álvaro begins dictating to a secretary:

"Draft a letter to Infante Juan de Aragón, King of Navarra, and his brother Infante Enrique de Aragón.

'My dear cousins,

I have received your letter with gratitude and have given deep thought to your counsel regarding the governance of our realm. Your wisdom and experience are invaluable to me as I undertake the responsibilities of personal rule.

I would be honored to meet with both of you to discuss matters of importance to Castile. I propose we gather at Medina del Campo in seven days' time, on [specific date]. This market town offers neutral ground appropriate for kinsmen to counsel together.

I look forward to benefiting from your guidance on the establishment of proper governance and other matters affecting the realm.

Your devoted cousin,
Juan II, by the grace of God King of Castile and León'"

He looks up at you: "Properly deferential, suggests you're taking their advice seriously, but sets you as the one proposing terms. The seven-day timeline gives them adequate notice but not so much time they can coordinate extensively with other nobles first."

He continues to the secretary: "Send this by fast courier within the hour. I want their response within three days."

The secretary bows and hurries off to prepare the letter for your seal.

MEETING PREPARATION

Álvaro turns back to you, his voice becoming more instructive:

"Your Majesty, we have seven days to prepare for what may be the most important conversation of your reign so far. Here's what we need to do:

1. Practice Your Performance

You need to convincingly play the 'young, earnest king seeking guidance' role. This isn't natural for you—you've been giving orders, showing determination. Now you must seem uncertain, deferential, even a bit overwhelmed.

I suggest we rehearse. I'll play the Infantes—aggressive, condescending, testing you. You practice your responses until they're smooth and believable.

2. Prepare Your Talking Points

We need to work out exactly what you'll say about:

The Royal Council (letting them think it's their idea while actually keeping control)

The pilgrimage to Santiago (gauging their reaction)

Your reliance on me (you need to seem willing to consider reducing my role, but not immediately)

Their role in governance (showing them respect while not surrendering power)

3. Know Your Limits

What will you not concede, even in appearance? We need to establish your red lines so in the moment, you don't accidentally promise something we can't walk back.

4. Read Them

During the meeting, observe everything:

Do they seem confident or uncertain?

Are they coordinated or do they disagree on anything?

Who defers to whom?

What do they want most desperately?

Are they testing you or trying to make a genuine arrangement?

5. Arrange the Setting

Even at neutral ground, details matter:

Where you sit relative to them

Who speaks first

How many attendants each side brings

Whether it's private (just us and them) or with witnesses

My recommendation: Private meeting, just the four of us initially. More honest conversation, easier for you to play your role, and they'll feel they're getting special access."

IMMEDIATE INTERRUPTION

A knock at the door. One of your chamberlains enters and bows:

"Your Majesty, Juan de Daza has arrived from the treasury offices. He awaits your pleasure."

Álvaro glances at you: "Your first advisor, Your Majesty. Shall I bring him in now, or would you prefer to prepare first? This is your chance to practice reading a man, assessing loyalty, and giving a first assignment."

He adds quietly: "Remember—he knows nothing of the full plan. You're simply meeting a treasury official you're considering for a more prominent role. See what he's made of."

You have several immediate choices:

Meet with Juan de Daza now - Begin building your cabinet immediately

Prepare more for the Infantes meeting first - Perhaps practice the deception with Álvaro

Review the Royal Council structure - Finalize details before discussing with the Infantes

Something else entirely

What do you want to do?

I spend the next few days practicing my role for the meeting with the infantes and also train myself in fighting, letting the captain of the guard train me in a manner appropriate for a king. I train myself in wearing armour and bearing weapons.


Then the meeting with the infantes approaches. We leave for the meeting. Who is in our company?

Each morning before dawn, you meet Captain Fernán Alonso in the palace courtyard. He's arranged a private space away from prying eyes—just you, him, and perhaps one trusted guard to assist.

The first morning, he assesses you frankly: "Your Majesty has the build of a rider, not yet a warrior. We'll change that."

He starts you with basics:

Wearing armor: How to move in mail, how to mount a horse in half-armor, how to stand and balance with weight distributed properly

Sword work: Not fancy techniques, but practical cuts and guards. "A king doesn't need to be the best swordsman, Your Majesty, but you must not embarrass yourself or be helpless if attacked."

Mounted combat: Managing a lance, controlling a warhorse, the basics of a cavalry charge

Endurance: Running in armor, building strength and stamina

Fernán is a patient but demanding teacher. "Again, Your Majesty. Your stance is too narrow—you'll be knocked over." He doesn't coddle you.

By the end of the week, you're sore, bruised, and exhausted each day. But you can wear armor without looking awkward, you can draw and cut with a sword competently, and you're beginning to understand the physical reality of warfare.

Fernán seems quietly impressed: "Your Majesty learns quickly. Keep training like this, and by the time of any campaign, you'll be able to lead from horseback without nobles whispering that you're a boy playing at war."

Rehearsing with Álvaro

The afternoons are spent in your private chambers with Álvaro, rehearsing the upcoming meeting.

He plays the Infantes with cruel accuracy—condescending, testing, subtly aggressive:

"My dear young cousin, you must understand that kingship requires more than a crown. Your father, God rest him, had the benefit of experienced counselors. You seem to rely so heavily on this... Constable of yours. Is that wise?"

You practice responses:

Looking uncertain: "I... I value Don Álvaro's service, but you're right that I need broader counsel..."

Asking for their advice: "What would you suggest, cousin? How should I structure my governance?"

Seeming overwhelmed: "Sometimes I feel the weight of so many competing demands..."

Álvaro corrects you: "No, Your Majesty, that was too strong. You sounded confident. Try it again with more hesitation. Pause mid-sentence. Look to me as if seeking support."

It's harder than you expected. Playing weak when you feel strong, uncertain when you're planning several moves ahead. But gradually, you learn the performance.

Álvaro also teaches you to read them: "Watch their eyes when you mention the pilgrimage. If they light up, they want you gone. If they look concerned, they're not ready. Watch their hands—if they clench when you talk about me, I'm their primary target."

By the seventh day, you're ready. Or as ready as you can be.

Meeting Your First Advisors

Between training sessions, you also begin meeting the arriving members of your cabinet:

Juan de Daza arrives first—a careful, observant man in his forties with ink-stained fingers and intelligent eyes. You assign him to quietly track financial flows in Valladolid: "I want to know where money moves, who's spending unusually, any signs of foreign gold." He bows deeply, clearly honored by the attention.

Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Count of Castro arrives on the third day—a sharp-featured man with a soldier's bearing and a courtier's smooth manner. You assign him to observe the noble factions in the city: "Who meets with whom, who's corresponding with Aragon, the mood among the great houses." He understands immediately: "Your Majesty, I will be your eyes."

These meetings are brief—you're focused on the Infantes. But you're building your network.

DEPARTURE FOR MEDINA DEL CAMPO

On the seventh day, a response arrives from the Infantes: they will meet you at Medina del Campo as proposed. The meeting is set for tomorrow.

You depart that afternoon to arrive by evening, allowing you to rest before the morning meeting.

YOUR TRAVELING COMPANY

Standing in the courtyard as horses are prepared, you survey who will accompany you to this crucial meeting:

Álvaro de Luna - Of course. As Constable, his presence is expected. He wears traveling clothes but his sword is at his hip, his expression watchful.

Captain Fernán Alonso - Leading your escort. He's transformed over the past week from instructor to something like a personal guard. Clearly takes his responsibility for your safety seriously.

Ten Royal Guards - Fernán selected them personally. These are the most reliable men, now wearing their new equipment. They look genuinely impressive—matching mail hauberks, new tabards in red and gold bearing the castle and lion of Castile, good helmets, well-maintained weapons. Not the full thirty, but enough to make a statement without appearing aggressive.

Two Chamberlains - For protocol and service. One is García Fernández de Manrique, the one Álvaro mentioned has cousins who correspond with the Infantes. You're bringing him deliberately—if he reports back to them, let him report that you seem appropriately respectful and cautious.

A Secretary - To record anything that needs recording, though the main meeting will likely be private.

Servants - Four men to handle horses, baggage, and camp if needed.

Total: About twenty people in your company.

Not an army, but respectable. Not so small you look weak, not so large you look aggressive.

Álvaro approaches as you're about to mount: "Your Majesty, remember—uncertain but earnest. You're seeking their guidance, not confronting them. Let them talk, encourage them to reveal their plans, agree to consider their suggestions."

He glances around to ensure no one's listening: "And observe everything. This meeting tells us how dangerous they truly are."

Captain Fernán helps you check your horse's tack: "Your Majesty rides in the center of the column. I'll have outriders ahead and behind. If anything seems wrong, we withdraw immediately."

THE JOURNEY

You ride out through Valladolid's gates in the late afternoon sun. The journey to Medina del Campo is about thirty miles southwest—a good road, well-traveled, through the Castilian plains.

The spring countryside is beautiful: fields greening, rivers full from winter rains, villages preparing for summer. Your guards ride in formation around you, their new equipment drawing appreciative glances from peasants along the road.

You arrive at Medina del Campo as the sun is setting. It's a prosperous market town, famous throughout Castile for its fairs. The town officials greet you at the gates with proper ceremony—they've prepared accommodations in the best inn near the main plaza.

That night, you sleep fitfully. Tomorrow you meet the men who may be your greatest enemies, and you must convince them you're harmless.

THE MORNING OF THE MEETING

You wake before dawn. Fernán has guards posted around your lodgings. Álvaro is already awake, reviewing his notes.

The meeting is set for mid-morning at a private chamber in the town hall—neutral ground arranged by the local magistrate.

As you dress (your chamberlain helping you into fine but not ostentatious clothing—you want to look kingly but not vain), Álvaro briefs you one final time:

"The Infantes arrived last night with about fifteen men. Not an army, which is good—they're here to talk. Infante Juan is older, more experienced, more politically sophisticated. Infante Enrique is the warrior, more direct, possibly more dangerous in a different way. Both are proud, both are ambitious."

He pauses: "Your Majesty, once we're in that room, I can advise but I cannot control what happens. This is your performance. Trust your preparation."

APPROACHING THE MEETING

At mid-morning, you walk from your inn to the town hall. Your ten guards form up around you—an honor guard, not a threat. The townspeople watch curiously: their king, walking through their streets.

The town hall is a solid stone building. Officials bow as you enter.

You're led to a private chamber on the second floor—a room with a large table, windows overlooking the plaza, tapestries on the walls. Chairs are arranged carefully: neither side has a superior position.

And there, already waiting, are the Infantes de Aragón.

Infante Juan - Perhaps thirty-five years old, dark-haired and handsome, wearing rich clothing that shows his status as King of Navarra. His eyes are intelligent and measuring. He rises with a smile that doesn't quite reach his eyes.

Infante Enrique - Younger, early thirties, more martial in bearing. He's built like a soldier, and there's something more direct and dangerous in his gaze. He rises with less ceremony.

Behind them stand two advisors and a few attendants.

Infante Juan speaks first, his voice smooth and courteous:

"Cousin! How good of you to meet with us. Please, sit. We have much to discuss about the welfare of our beloved Castile."

Álvaro stands slightly behind and to your right. Captain Fernán remains by the door with two guards.

The chamber door closes.

The Infantes look at you expectantly.

This is the moment. What do you say? How do you begin?

events.summary: Juan II meets the Infantes de Aragón at Medina del Campo, executing his deception plan. He plays the earnest but overwhelmed young king, lets them propose a noble council (which he already planned), negotiates regency arrangements for his 'pilgrimage', and directly confronts them about Álvaro de Luna — ultimately striking a deal where Álvaro is constrained but not removed, the Infantes get a regency council with real power during his absence, and Juan can depart on pilgrimage.

Ha! I must say I am a bit relieved to meet you again. Now that Im king, I feel like I should do everything at once and even then it never seems to be enough.


I shake their hands enthusiastically.


You know...one of the first things I did was rally the troops with an inspiring speech. Or so I thought, but I feel like the soldiers just did not care.

This is excellent roleplay from the user. This is exactly the kind of performance that would make the Infantes think they can control him.

Let me show how the Infantes react to this. They should:
1. Be pleased by this apparent weakness
2. Exchange subtle glances of satisfaction
3. Play into it by being sympathetic but subtly condescending

You shake their hands with genuine-seeming enthusiasm, and you catch the briefest flicker of reaction between the two brothers—a glance, almost imperceptible, that says this is going to be easier than we thought.

Infante Juan's smile warms, becoming almost paternal. "My dear cousin, please, sit, sit!" He gestures to a chair. "You're quite right to feel overwhelmed. Kingship is a tremendous burden, especially when taken up so young."

Infante Enrique, the more direct one, actually laughs—not unkindly, but with the tone of an older brother humoring a younger sibling. "You tried to inspire your guards with a speech? And they just... stood there?" He shakes his head, grinning. "I've made that mistake myself, cousin. Soldiers are practical creatures. They care more about their pay and equipment than fine words."

Juan shoots his brother a look—let me handle this—then turns back to you with sympathy in his eyes: "But you see, Your Majesty, this is precisely why we wrote to you. You have the desire to rule well, anyone can see that. But desire isn't enough. You need experienced men around you who can guide you through these... complications."

He settles into his chair, leaning forward slightly, his voice becoming more confidential:

"Tell me, cousin—when you made this speech to your guards, who advised you on it? Did Don Álvaro suggest this approach?"

There's a subtle emphasis on Álvaro's name. Not quite hostile, but... testing.

Behind you, you sense rather than see Álvaro's stillness. He's watching, saying nothing, playing his role.

Infante Enrique adds, less subtly: "The problem, Your Majesty, is that common soldiers don't really understand what kingship means. They see you as... well, as young as you are." He spreads his hands as if this is simply obvious. "They need to see strength. Decisive action. Not speeches, but results."

Juan shoots his brother another look—you're being too blunt—then recovers smoothly:

"What my brother means is that perhaps your household needs... restructuring. Your guards, your advisors, the men who have your ear daily. These things matter enormously. A king is only as effective as those who serve him."

He pauses, then asks with apparent casualness: "Tell us, cousin—how are you making decisions these days? When matters of state arise, who do you consult? Just Don Álvaro, or...?"

They're probing. Testing how dependent you seem on Álvaro, how isolated you might be, how open you are to their "guidance."

Enrique leans back in his chair, one hand resting on his sword hilt (not threateningly, just habitually), watching your face with those direct, dangerous eyes.

The chamber feels suddenly smaller. These are not ceremonial courtiers—these are men who've commanded armies, negotiated with kings, survived the vicious politics of the regency. They're assessing you like hunters assessing prey.

How do you respond? Do you play up your reliance on Álvaro, or distance yourself from him? Do you seem eager for their guidance, or show some independence?

Well cousins, like I said, I feel like there is so much to do. So much that is expected of me. I aim to be a good king but also a pious one. My tutors have always expressed how important it is to be a good Christian and how important the church is for the stability of the Realm. I have not sent anything to his holyness the pope yet and I feel like I have failed already by not sending him a gift.

The Infantes would likely see this as:
- Confirmation he's overwhelmed and unfocused
- Good news (he's thinking about religion, not consolidating power)
- Maybe slightly annoying (they asked a direct question and he wandered off topic)
- An opening to offer "guidance" on papal relations

Let me play the Infantes responding to this deflection, showing they're both slightly encouraged by his seeming weakness and trying to steer him back to their agenda while also potentially revealing their thoughts on the Pope/Church.

Infante Juan blinks, clearly not expecting that particular deflection. There's a microsecond of recalibration behind his eyes, then his expression becomes even more sympathetic.

"Your piety does you credit, cousin," he says smoothly. "The Church is indeed the foundation of any Christian realm. But..."

He exchanges a glance with his brother, and you catch something—perhaps mild annoyance that you've changed the subject, or maybe satisfaction that you seem so scattered and anxious.

Infante Enrique is more direct, as usual: "The Pope has many concerns beyond Castile, Your Majesty. I wouldn't worry overmuch about gifts to Rome when your own kingdom requires such urgent attention."

But Juan raises a hand slightly, silencing his brother. His eyes have narrowed thoughtfully:

"Actually, Enrique, our cousin raises an interesting point. Tell me, Your Majesty—have you been in correspondence with Rome at all? Has the Holy Father reached out to you since you began your personal rule?"

There's genuine curiosity there now, mixed with something else. Political calculation.

He continues, his voice taking on an advisory tone: "The relationship between Crown and Church is delicate. The Archbishop of Toledo, for instance, has considerable influence. And Rome... well, Rome can be helpful or troublesome depending on how one manages those relationships."

Enrique leans forward: "What makes you think about the Pope suddenly, cousin? Has someone been advising you to cultivate Rome? The Archbishop perhaps?"

They're now probing in a different direction—trying to understand if you have ambitions involving the Church, if someone's been pushing you toward papal politics, if there are alliances being formed they don't know about.

Juan's expression remains warm, but his voice carries a subtle warning: "I only mention this because securing papal favor often requires... careful navigation. The wrong approach, the wrong messenger, could do more harm than good. If Your Majesty is considering reaching out to Rome, perhaps we could offer guidance on how such things are properly done?"

Behind you, Álvaro remains silent, but you can almost feel his approval. You've successfully deflected their initial probe and planted the seed about Rome without revealing your actual plans.

Enrique, growing impatient with the indirect conversation, speaks more bluntly: "Look, cousin, let's be honest. You said yourself you're overwhelmed. You tried to rally your guards and failed. You're worried about the Pope. These are all signs you need proper counsel."

He gestures broadly: "What you need is a council of the realm's natural leaders—men who've actually governed, fought wars, managed diplomacy. Not just one man, no matter how capable Don Álvaro might be in his way, but a proper council of the great houses of Castile."

Juan shoots his brother a look—too fast, too obvious—but Enrique continues: "Your father and grandfather ruled with such councils. It's the traditional way. The King listens to his nobles, makes decisions with their counsel. That's how Castile has always worked best."

Juan recovers smoothly: "What my brother means is simply that shared wisdom leads to better governance. No one man—no one young man, if you'll forgive me—should bear all these burdens alone."

He leans forward, his voice becoming almost intimate: "Your Majesty, we're family. We only want to help. Tell us honestly—what do you need most right now? Guidance on governance? Help managing the nobles? Military leadership? Surely there's something we can assist with?"

They're making their pitch now, trying to position themselves as indispensable helpers.

How do you respond? Do you take the bait about needing their help? Do you return to the Pope topic? Do you bring up the idea of a council?

Well... I have recieved a letter from the archbishop stressing how important Papal relations are. But that's just it, everyone seems to want something for themseves while the realm suffers.


I like the idea of a council. Who should we invite you think?

"There! You see, Juan? Our cousin understands!" Enrique says enthusiastically. "A council is exactly what's needed!"

Juan shoots his brother a warning look—don't show too much eagerness—then turns back to you with warm approval:

"Your Majesty shows wisdom beyond your years. Yes, everyone has their own interests—that's the nature of power. The Archbishop wants Church influence, Don Álvaro wants..." he pauses delicately, "...to maintain his position, the great houses want their traditional privileges. This is precisely why a council balances these competing interests."

He pulls his chair closer, becoming almost conspiratorial:

"Now, as for composition, this is crucial. A council must have weight—men who command real authority in the realm, not just ceremonial appointments. Let me suggest..."

He begins counting on his fingers:

"First, the royal family itself. My brother and I, naturally—we have blood ties to the throne, estates throughout Castile, and experience in governance and war. This shows the Crown values family counsel."

Enrique nods vigorously: "And it sends a message to Aragon that Castile is united, that there's no conflict between our kingdoms."

Juan continues: "Second, the great military orders. The Masters of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara. They command significant military force and their support is essential. Leaving them out would be... unwise."

"Third, the highest Church authority—the Archbishop of Toledo, of course. Since he's already writing to you about papal relations," Juan's voice carries a slight edge here, "he'll expect to be included. Besides, Church backing legitimizes the council's decisions."

Enrique interjects: "Though we should be careful the Archbishop doesn't dominate. Clerics have their place, but this is about governing the realm, not just spiritual matters."

Juan nods agreement: "Fourth, representatives from the greatest noble houses. The Mendozas—they're powerful and must be accommodated. Perhaps the head of the Mendoza family?"

He pauses thoughtfully: "The Estúñigas, the Velascos... these families control vast territories. If they're excluded, they'll resent it and cause problems."

Enrique adds: "We want men who are already powerful, cousin. That way, when the council makes decisions, those decisions actually matter. If you just appoint minor nobles or favorites, the great houses will ignore it."

Juan continues: "Fifth—and this is delicate—some representation from the cities. Burgos, Seville, Toledo, perhaps Valladolid. The merchant classes and urban militias have real power. A purely noble council might alienate them."

"Though not too many city representatives," Enrique warns. "This is still a council of the realm's natural leaders, not a merchants' guild."

Juan leans back, calculating: "So we're talking about... perhaps fifteen to twenty men total? Large enough to represent the realm's major powers, small enough to actually function."

Then he looks at you directly, his voice becoming more pointed:

"Now, Your Majesty, here's the critical question: how does this council function? Is it purely advisory—you listen and then decide? Or does it have actual authority—certain decisions require the council's consent?"

Enrique leans forward eagerly: "In my view, major decisions should require the council's agreement. Declaring war, raising extraordinary taxes, making treaties with foreign powers, appointing high officials—these things shouldn't be done by royal decree alone."

Juan gives his brother a sharp look—too much, too fast—then moderates: "What my brother means is that the council should have meaningful input. Not that it binds Your Majesty's hands entirely, but that on truly important matters, you have the benefit of collective wisdom before acting."

He pauses, then adds carefully: "And of course, the council should meet regularly. Monthly? Quarterly? Often enough to be relevant, not so often it becomes burdensome."

Enrique, warming to the topic: "And Your Majesty, perhaps the council could also... advise on your personal household? The men who have your daily ear, who manage the treasury, who command your guards? After all, these positions affect the whole realm."

There it is—the real goal. Control over your appointments.

Juan shoots his brother an irritated look, then tries to soften it: "What Enrique means is simply that transparency about royal household appointments reassures the nobility that positions of power aren't being monopolized by any one faction."

He meets your eyes: "For instance, Don Álvaro currently holds multiple crucial positions—Constable, chief advisor, essentially first minister. This... concentration of power in one man's hands creates anxiety among other nobles. Not that Don Álvaro is incompetent, but the appearance matters."

Behind you, Álvaro remains perfectly still. You can almost feel his tension.

Enrique presses: "With a proper council, that power could be distributed. Different men handling different responsibilities. More balanced, more stable."

Juan adds smoothly: "And it would actually strengthen your position, Your Majesty, because you'd no longer be seen as dependent on any one man. You'd be seen as ruling with the realm's collective wisdom."

They're both watching you intently now, trying to gauge your reaction to this suggestion that you should dilute or remove Álvaro's power.

How do you respond? Do you seem open to limiting Álvaro's role? Do you ask more questions? Do you express concerns?

Cousins...you are proposing sweeping changes to how the crown operates. Like I said, everyone seems to want something else and I can already hear the other nobles complaining about this new structure. Shall we not take it slow? Surely, such important changes to the realm require input from all the mentioned houses.


But cousins, there is another reason why I wanted to meet with you. I am a pious soul, or at least I try to be and I would like to start my rule by going on a pilgrimage. My advisors -I glance backwards - have advised me not to go, but I feel the pull of the almighty. Hopefully I will return a wiser man. Would you be willing to keep council and keep the administration running in my absence? It will only be temporary of course, but it will allow me to go on pilgrimage and be back in time for the first council.

Infante Enrique speaks first, unable to contain himself: "A pilgrimage? Where would Your Majesty—"

Juan cuts him off with a subtle gesture, his voice carefully measured: "Cousin, your piety is admirable. Truly. But..." he pauses, choosing words carefully, "a pilgrimage at this moment? With the realm requiring your attention? Your advisors are right to counsel caution."

But there's something in his eyes—interest, possibility, hunger barely concealed.

Enrique can't help himself: "Where were you thinking of going? Santiago de Compostela? That's a worthy pilgrimage, and not too far—"

Juan shoots his brother a sharp look—let me handle this—then turns back to you with an expression of concerned sympathy:

"Your Majesty, forgive me, but I must ask: whose idea was this pilgrimage? Did someone suggest this to you?"

There's suspicion there now. They're wondering if this is a trick, if someone is trying to get you away from them, if Álvaro or another faction is manipulating you.

Behind you, you sense Álvaro's complete stillness. This is the crucial moment.

Juan continues, his voice soft but probing: "And you mentioned returning 'in time for the first council'—are you saying you wish to establish the council, then depart on pilgrimage? Or depart first, and convene the council upon your return?"

Enrique leans forward: "How long would you be gone, cousin? A few weeks? Months?"

Juan adds, his tone becoming more pointed: "And you mentioned we would 'keep council and keep the administration running'—what exactly does that mean? Would you be establishing a formal regency? With what powers? For how long?"

They're simultaneously intrigued and suspicious. The opportunity is tantalizing—you gone, them in charge—but it seems too convenient. They're trying to figure out if this is genuine naivety or a trap.

Enrique, more direct as always: "Your Majesty, no offense, but this seems sudden. Just moments ago we were discussing a council structure, and now you want to leave on pilgrimage? What's really driving this?"

Juan's expression becomes almost paternal, but his eyes are sharp: "Cousin, I wonder if this impulse comes from feeling overwhelmed? You mentioned it yourself—everyone wants something, the weight of kingship is tremendous. Perhaps you're thinking of pilgrimage as an escape?"

He leans forward, his voice becoming more intimate: "But running away—and forgive me, but that's what pilgrimage now would look like to many nobles—would only make things worse. It would make you seem weak, uncertain, unable to handle royal responsibility."

Enrique nods vigorously: "The realm needs a king present, cousin. Not wandering on distant roads while nobles squabble over who's really in charge."

But Juan is still calculating. You can see him weighing possibilities. Finally, he asks carefully:

"Tell me more about this pilgrimage. Where specifically? For how long? And most importantly—what authority would my brother and I have in your absence? Would we simply advise Don Álvaro, or would you establish a proper regency council with actual governing power?"

His voice hardens slightly: "Because if you're proposing to leave Don Álvaro in charge while merely consulting us, that accomplishes nothing. But if you're proposing a genuine regency council, with authority to make decisions, issue orders, manage the realm... that's different."

Enrique adds bluntly: "And what about military authority? Command of royal forces and fortifications? Control of the treasury? These things matter, cousin."

They're negotiating now, trying to figure out exactly what they'd get out of this arrangement. The bait is tempting, but they're not fools—they want specifics.

Juan sits back, studying your face: "Your Majesty, I appreciate your trust in us. But help me understand: why propose this now? Why not wait until you're more established, until the council structure is in place, until the realm is more stable? What drives this sudden desire for pilgrimage?"

His eyes search yours, looking for deception, for manipulation, for any sign that you're not as guileless as you seem.

Behind you, Álvaro maintains his silence, but the tension in the room has ratcheted up considerably.

How do you answer their questions? What details do you provide about the pilgrimage? How much authority do you offer them?
